loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell.

loans.name: Mrs. Ton Sokunthea Village Bank Group

texts.en:
Mrs. Ton S. is a village bank president who has been selected by ten members of this group loan in Angk Neareay village in Takeo province. She is a mother of three children, two of whom are attending the local public school. The other is not going to school yet. 

She is a breeder of pigs and chickens who is earning some money to support her family while her husband, Mr. Chantha Sou, is a motorbike taxi driver. 

Since her animal breeding is getting on well, she wants to expand. So Mrs. Ton S. is requesting a loan to buy more chickens, piglets, and chicken and duck food.

loans.use: To buy more chickens, piglets, and animal feed

loans.name: Ariunbileg

texts.en: Ariunbileg is 34 years old and lives in the Tuv province of Mongolia. He is a single man and lives in a rented house. His parents and siblings live in the countryside. He started his wooden product business in 1998. He is popular in his area as a highly skilled, talented carpenter and wood engraver. He has made a professional fiddle, a highly respected traditional musical instrument of the Mongolian people, commissioned by the local administration house of the province. He operates his business with a partner. He wants to expand his business and establish a corporation. He is requesting a loan of 2,000,000 MNT to buy more wood, as the price in the market is lower these days.

loans.use: To buy more wood

loans.name: Gantsetseg

texts.en:
Gantsetseg, 39, lives with her two daughters in the Uvurhangai province of Mongolia. They live an a rented apartment and both of her daughters attend a local secondary school. 

She started a computer-service business in 2007. She started her business at the right time as now she has a stable income source. Besides supporting her family, she has created a workplace and she has a co-worker. She works hard to satisfy the needs of her customers and the photos and papers that are printed out in her office attract people with their quality. Showing a quality service is the advantage of her business. 

Gantsetseg is a hardworking, sociable and active person whose dream is to expand her business and to open a big computer-service center. She is requesting a loan of 1,500,000 Mongolian tugriks to buy more supplies and for maintenance.

loans.use: To buy more supplies and for maintenance

loans.name: Tsetsegtuya

texts.en:
Tsetsegtuya, 37, is married and lives with her husband and two children in Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia. Her husband is self-employed.  Both of her children are attending a local secondary school. They have a decent standard of living.

Tsetsegtuya started a clothes trading business at Narantuul, the biggest outdoor market in Ulaanbaatar. She started her business with a working capital of 1,000,000 MNT. Now, her business is more stable – she has been renting the same stall where she now sells for a long period of time. 

Tsetsegtuya  lives close to Narantuul market.  This is an advantage for her as she does not need to spend much money on  transportation. She is a sociable person whose desperate wish is to have her own apartment. 

Tsetsegtuya is requesting a loan of 800,000 MNT to buy more seasonal clothing to sell this season.

loans.use: To buy more seasonal clothing to sell

loans.name: Mr. Koy Touch Village Bank Group

texts.en:
In the village of Angk Neareay in Takeo Province, twelve people have made up a village bank group to request a loan. Each member will use his or her portion of the loan for different purposes to improve his or her family's living.

Mr. Koy T. is a village bank president who has been selected by the other members. He and his wife, Mrs. S. Kuov, are farmers who own a 2-hectare plot of land where they grow rice to sell to support their family. Mr. Koy T. also breeds some cows. To improve rice production in his field, Mr. Koy T. is requesting a loan to buy rice seed, fertilizer, and gasoline. He is the father of two children. One of his children is a farmer, and his other child attends local public school.

loans.use: To buy rice seed, fertilizer, and gasoline

loans.name: Ma. Corazon

texts.en:
Ma. Corazon is a married woman who lives in Bago City, Negros Occidental. She earns her living by operating a business buying and selling rice grains. Her husband Alfredo G. D., who is 46 years old, works as a farmer to earn his living.  He also helps with his wife's business activities. They have 2 children who are 26 and 28 years old – one is married and one is currently working. 

Ma. Corazon joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2010 because she aspired for something better for her family. With the help of her past loan from NWTF-Project Dungganon, Ma. Corazon has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty by the sweat of her brow. Her previous loan of PHP 5000 helped her earn a monthly profit of PHP 10000, uplifting the family's standard of living.  This time, for her 2nd loan, she is borrowing PHP 10000, which she intends to use to purchase more stock of palay and rice so that she can continue to save to provide a better life and future for her family. 

Ma. Corazon is a Dungganon woman who is following an honorable path toward the achievement of her dreams. 

About NWTF: In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work. Help NWTF continue its mission to help the poorest in the Philippines by clicking  the link to the   NWTF Kiva lending team  on Kiva.org to join our team.

loans.use: Purchase more stock to sell

loans.name: Ma. Elena

texts.en:
Ma. Elena is 36-years old.  She is married and supports her family by operating a business selling assorted items. She lives in Bago City, Negros Occidental. She has been a member of NWTF-Project Dungganon since 2001 and has improved her living conditions with the help of her loans from NWTF and through her own efforts. 

By working hard in her  business, she is gradually making her family more economically stable. She now earns an average monthly income of PHP 18000. Ma. Elena is borrowing PHP 15000 so that she can purchase more stocks to sell. This will be her 18th loan from NWTF-Project Dungganon. Her previous loan of PHP 11000, which she paid off well within its term, was just another step in her journey toward economic freedom. 

Ma. Elena aspires to elevate her family's living conditions and ensure their future well-being by following the Dungganon way. 

About NWTF: In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work. Help NWTF continue its mission to help the poorest in the Philippines by clicking  the link to the   NWTF Kiva lending team  on Kiva.org to join our team.

loans.use: Purchase more stock to sell

loans.name: Mrs. Nou Ngon Village Bank Group

texts.en:
Mrs. Nou N. is a tailor who is able to earn some money to support her family. She is also a chicken and pig breeder. Her husband, Mr. Em Mean, is a farmer. He owns a small piece of land and grows rice to support the family. He also sells brooms. Mrs. Nou N. is the mother of a construction worker. Since her business is getting on well, she wants to expand. Mrs. Nou N. is applying for a loan to buy more chickens. 

This village bank includes ten people who have selected Mrs. Nou N. to be the village bank president. They are located in Angk Neareay village in Takeo province.

loans.use: To buy more chickens

loans.name: Remia

texts.en:
Remia is a widow who lives in Bago City, Negros Occidental. She earns her living by operating a business selling dried fish.  She has six children between 16 and 30 years old – 2 of them have families of  their own, 2 are working, and the other 2 are currently going to school. 

Remia joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 1999 because she aspired for something better for her family. With the help of her past 24 loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, Remia has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty by the sweat of her brow. Her previous loan of PHP 12000 helped her earn a monthly profit of PHP 20000, uplifting the family's standard of living. This time, for her 25th loan, she is borrowing PHP 20000, which she intends to use as additional working capital so that she can continue to save up for the education of her children and for future needs.   Remia is a Dungganon woman who is following an honorable path toward the achievement of her dreams. 

About NWTF: In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work. Help NWTF continue its mission to help the poorest in the Philippines by clicking  the link to the   NWTF Kiva lending team  on Kiva.org to join our team.

loans.use: Working capital

loans.name: Mrs. Nhoem Khema Village Bank Group

texts.en:
Mrs. Nhoem K. is a weaver who earns some money to support her famiL., while her husband, Mr. Mala Soun, is a farmer. He owns a small piece of land and grows rice to support the famiL.. She is the mother of three children: one is a weaver and the others are still in school. Since her business is going well, Mrs. Nhoem K. wants to expand. She is applying for a loan to buy more silk for weaving. 

This village bank is made up of 15 people from Chumrov village, Takeo province. Mrs. Nhoem K. is the village bank president, selected by the other members. Each member will use their portion of the loan in various ways to improve their famiL.'s standard of living.

loans.use: To buy more silk for weaving

loans.name: Feby

texts.en:
Feby is a 36-year old single woman who supports her family by operating a general store. She lives in Bago City, Negros Occidental. She has been a member of NWTF-Project Dungganon since 2009 and has improved her living conditions with the help of her loans from NWTF and through her own efforts. 

By working hard in her general store business, she is gradually making her family more economically stable. She now earns an average monthly income of PHP 5000. 

Feby is borrowing PHP 9000 so that she can purchase more stocks to sell. This will be her 4th loan from NWTF-Project Dungganon. Her previous loan of PHP 7000, which she paid off well within its term, was just another step on her journey toward economic freedom. Feby aspires to elevate her family's living conditions and ensure their future well-being by following the Dungganon way. 

About NWTF: In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work. Help NWTF continue its mission to help the poorest in the Philippines by clicking  the link to the   NWTF Kiva lending team  on Kiva.org to join our team.

loans.use: To purchase more stock to sell

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: TO BUY CORN AT WHOLESALE FOR MAKING TORTILLAS

loans.name: María Del Carmen

texts.es: María Del Carmen P. D. B. D. 30 años D. edad, resiD. en Mejicanos en el departamento D. San Salvador. Ella vive junto a su esposo y tres hijos menores D. edad. María es una madre D. familia muy responsable y trabajadora, la cual se dedica a la comercialización D. ropa para mujeres como: pantalones, chumpas, camisetas y faldas, el negocio se encuentra en su casa D. habitación y es bastante estable. María solicita un préstamo a Integral a través del cual pueda comprar mayor cantidad D. ropa, así D. esta manera hacer crecer su venta y al mismo tiempo obtener mayores ganancias.
texts.en: María Del Carmen P. D. B. is 30 years old and lives in Mejicanos, in the San Salvador department, along with her husband and three young children.  She is a very responsible and hard working mother who sells women’s clothing, sweaters, t-shirts, and skirts.  Her business is stable and she runs her business out of her home.  María is requesting this loan through Integral so she can buy clothing in quantity and be able to increase her sales and income.

loans.use: Inventory

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Clothes making supplies

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Beauty supplies

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Inventory (shoes)

loans.name: Dolores  Roxana

texts.es: Dolores  Roxana S. M. de 29 años de edad, reside en el departamento de Chalatenango,  en donde vive junto a su esposo y sus pequeños hijo. Dolores es una persona muy responsable, la cual cuenta con muy buenas referencias por parte de sus vecinos. Ella  posee una tienda en la cual comercializa productos perecederos  y de primera necesidad. Dolores cuenta con muy buena ubicación y es esto lo cual le permite contar con más cantidad de clientes, los cuales la prefieren por ser una persona muy amable. Dolores desea poder surtir su negocio, comprando productos nuevos como golosinas, pasta dental y otros más. Ella desea poder aumentar sus ventas, ya que es esta la única fuente de ingresos que ella tiene para poder brindarle a su familia todo lo necesario para tener una vida aceptable en la cual se cuente con lo más básico.
texts.en: Dolores Roxana S. M. is 29 years old and lives with her husband and small children in the Chalatenango department.  Dolores is a very responsible person with good references from her neighbors.  She has a store where she sells primary needs products and perishable items.  The store is in a good location, which allows her to have more customers, who prefer buying from her because she is very friendly.  Dolores would like to stock her store buy buying new products such as snacks, toothpaste, and other things.  She would like to increase her sales, since this is her only source of income she has with which to provide for her family’s needs and be able to give them an acceptable life.  At the moment, they only have the basic needs.

loans.use: Inventory

loans.name: Concepción

texts.es: Concepción J. H. de 49 años de edad, reside en el departamento de Chalatenango, junto a su esposa y cuatro hijos quienes dependen por completo de del trabajo de su padre. Concepción posee una venta de hamacas con la cual cuenta desde hace varios años atrás, él es una persona muy agradecida con la vida, ya que goza de la bendición de poseer un negocio propio que le ha permitido brindarle todo lo necesario a su familia, la cual la es la principal razón por la que se esfuerza día con día. La venta de hamacas la realiza de forma ambulante en donde cada día muy temprano Concepción  carga sus hamacas desde su hogar hasta las calles de Chalatenango, ofreciéndosela a diferentes clientes,  con el deseo  de vender la mayor cantidad  de su producto, y con la ilusión de poder obtener muy buenas ganancias, que le permitan ofrecerle una mejor vida a su familia. Es por esto que él solicita un préstamo a través del cual pueda contar con el dinero necesario para comprar mayor cantidad de hamacas.
texts.en:
Concepción J. H. is 49 years old and lives with his wife and four children in the Chalatenango department.  They all depend on him for support.   Concepción has been selling hammocks for several years.  He is very grateful for life and is happy to be blessed with having his own business because it allows him to provide for his family’s needs.  This is the main reason for his daily effort.

He sells on foot and every day, early in the morning, Concepción carries his hammocks along the streets of Chalatenango, offering them to different customers, hoping to sell large numbers so that he can generate a good income with which to provide his family with a better life.  He is asking for this loan so that he can buy a large quantity of hammocks.

loans.use: Inventory

loans.name: María Sara

texts.es: María Sara M. D. G. D. 51 años D. edad, resiD. en el departamento D. Chalatenango, junto a su esposo y tres hijos menores D. edad. Ella posee una venta D. frutas y verduras la cual esta ubicada en su casa D. habitación. DesD. hace varios años que ella cuenta con este negocio, el cual les ha permitido tener una vida llena D. todo lo básico necesario para sobrevivir, razón por la cual solicita un préstamo, ya que María desea poder comprar más frutas y verduras al por mayor con el fin D. poder comprar a menor precio y D. esta forma ofrecer su productos a menores precios que su competencia. Tanto María como su esposo son un matrimonio muy trabajador, los cuales se esfuerzan por una vida mejor para sus hijos quienes son lo primordial en sus vidas.
texts.en: María Sara M. D. G. is 51 years old and lives with her husband and three young children in the Chalatenango department.  She sells fruits and vegetables out of her home.  She has had this business for several years, and it allows her to proviD. a life with all the basic needs for survival.  She is asking for this loan so that she can buy more fruits and vegetables in quantity.  Buying in quantity will allow her to buy at lower prices and be able to sell at prices below the competition.  Like María, her husband is also a very hard worker.  They work together to be able to proviD. a better life for their children, who are their top priority.

loans.use: Inventory

loans.name: Agnes

texts.en:
Agnes is a married woman who lives in E.B. Magalona, Negros Occidental. She earns her living by operating 3 business ventures: a junk shop, a drilling and plumbing business, and a business buying and selling Jeep parts. Her husband, Wilfred Ryan G., who is 37 years old years old, manages the junk shop business. They have a child who is 11 years old and is currently going to school. 

Agnes joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2002 because she aspired for something better for her family. With the help of her past 13 loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, Agnes has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty by the sweat of her brow. Her previous loan of PHP 19,000 helped her earn a monthly profit of PHP 30,000, uplifting the family's standard of living.  This time, for her 14th loan, she is borrowing PHP 19,000, which she intends to use as funds for the business operations, so that she can continue to save up for the future of her family and for her child’s education. Agnes is a Dungganon woman who is following an honorable path toward the achievement of her dreams. 

About NWTF: In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work. Help NWTF continue its mission to help the poorest in the Philippines by clicking  the link to the   NWTF Kiva lending team  on Kiva.org to join our team.

loans.use: To fund business operations

loans.name: Jennifer

texts.en:
Jennifer is a married woman who lives in E.B. Magalona, Negros Occidental. She earns her living by operating 2 business ventures: fishing and a ready-to-wear business. Her husband Ramie B., who is 30 years old, works as a fisherman to earn income. They have 4 children between 11 to 15 years old, who are currently going to school. 

Jennifer joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2008 because she aspired for something better for her family. With the help of her past 4 loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, Jennifer has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty by the sweat of her brow. Her previous loan of PHP 12,000 helped her earn a monthly profit of PHP 3,500, uplifting the family's standard of living.  This time, for her 5th loan, she is borrowing PHP 17,000, which she intends to use to purchase fishing nets so that she can continue to save up for future family needs and for her children's education. Jennifer is a Dungganon woman who is following an honorable path toward the achievement of her dreams.

loans.use: To buy fishing nets and supplies

loans.name: Lougina

texts.en:
Lougina is 41 years old.  She is married and supports her family by operating 3 business ventures:  a piggery, a frozen food business, and a junk shop. She lives in E.B. Magalona, Negros Occidental. 

Lougina has been a member of NWTF-Project Dungganon since 2002 and has improved her living conditions with the help of her loans from NWTF and through her own efforts. By working hard in her businesses, she is gradually making her family more economically stable. She now earns an average monthly income of PHP 2,000. 

Lougina is borrowing PHP 10,000 as additional revolving capital for all her business ventures. This will be her 16th loan from NWTF-Project Dungganon. Her previous loan of PHP 8,000, which she paid off well within its term, was just another step on her journey toward economic freedom. Lougina aspires to elevate her family's living conditions and ensure their future well-being by following the Dungganon way.

loans.use: additional working capital

loans.name: Lynette

texts.en:
Lynette is 46 years old.  She is married and supports her family by operating 3 business ventures:   a sewing business, a cloth fabrication business, and a tricycle operator business. She lives in E.B. Magalona, Negros Occidental. 

She has been a member of NWTF-Project Dungganon since 2007 and has improved her living conditions with the help of her loans from NWTF and through her own efforts. By working hard in her businesses, she is gradually making her family more economically stable. She now earns an average monthly income of PHP 10,000. 

Lynette is borrowing PHP 15,000 to fund her business operations. This will be her 8th loan from NWTF-Project Dungganon. Her previous loan of PHP 12,000, which she paid off well within its term, was just another step on her journey toward economic freedom. Lynette aspires to elevate her family's living conditions and ensure their future well-being by following the Dungganon way.

loans.use: To fund business operations

loans.name: Jacquelyn's Group

texts.en:
Jacquelyn G. is from the village of Brgy. Tucal, Solano, Nueva Vizcaya. She is 24 years old. Jacquelyn is the group leader of an 8-member group loan offered by ASKI. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults.

Jacquelyn is married and has 3 school-aged children. To make a living, Jacquelyn owns and operates a tricycle transport business. Jacquelyn has been engaged in her business for over 10 years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month from these activities.

In 2008, Jacquelyn joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Jacquelyn has successfully repaid a previous loan of 11,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase tires and other accessories. 

Jacquelyn is requesting a new loan of 11,000 PHP, which will be used to repair her vehicle to provide better service. This loan will be the 6th loan taken out by Jacquelyn from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to support her family. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 38 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To repair vehicle

loans.name: Martha

texts.en:
Martha is a married woman who lives in E.B. Magalona, Negros Occidental. She earns her living by operating 4 business ventures: buying and selling dry goods, a general store, a piggery, and a farming business. Her husband Eugenio B., who is 61 years old years old, receives income from a pension.  They have 3 children between 25 and 33 years old – all are married. 

Martha joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2000 because she aspired for something better for her family. With the help of her past 18 loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, Martha has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty by the sweat of her brow. 

Martha's previous loan of PHP 10,000 helped her earn a monthly profit of PHP 10,000, uplifting the family's standard of living. This time, for her 19th loan, she is borrowing PHP 25,000, which she intends to use to purchase more stocks to sell so that she can continue to save for her family's future needs. Martha is a Dungganon woman who is following an honorable path toward the achievement of her dreams.

loans.use: Purchase more stock to sell

loans.name: Melinde

texts.en:
Melinde is 44 years old.  She is married and supports her family by operating 3 business ventures:  a general store, a shrimp trading business, and a fishing business.  She lives in E.B. Magalona, Negros Occidental. 

She has been a member of NWTF-Project Dungganon since 2003 and has improved her living conditions with the help of her loans from NWTF and through her own efforts. By working hard in her businesses, she is gradually making her family more economically stable. She now earns an average monthly income of PHP 10,000.

Melinde is borrowing PHP 28,000 so that she can fund her business operations. This will be her 13th loan from NWTF-Project Dungganon. Her previous loan of PHP 23,000, which she repaid within its term, was just another step on her journey toward economic freedom. Melinde aspires to elevate her family's living conditions and ensure their future well-being by following the Dungganon way.

loans.use: To fund business operations

loans.name: Shamigul

texts.en:
Shamigul is divorced and cares for her two children who live with her. She supports her family with a business selling groceries. She has been in this business for 3 years and has gained experience as an entrepreneur and a salesperson. One of the things Shamigul enjoys most about her business is the opportunity to help her customers get healthy and nutritious foods. She tries to have a variety of products on hand so that she can offer a range of choices and meet each customer's needs. 

Shamigul's goal is to continue to learn and improve her business. She has requested a loan for 3500 Somoni to purchase additional inventory. Winter time is a very busy season for many grocery market vendors in Dushanbe. This loan will enable Shamigul to be prepared for the increased demand and earn some additional income that will help her and her family.   

More about Tajikistan and IMON International

Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions.

But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

IMON's History:

Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: To purchase additional inventory

loans.name: Yolanda's Group

texts.en:
Yolanda B. is from the village of Brgy. Bagahabag, Solano, Nueva Vizcaya. She is 53 years old. Yolanda is the group leader of a 6-member group loan offered by ASKI. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults.

Yolanda is married and has 5 adult children. To make a living, Yolanda owns and operates a general store. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from selling food and daily use products in the local community. Yolanda has been engaged in her business for over 5 years and earns approximately 3000 PHP a month from these activities.

In 2011, Yolanda joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Yolanda is requesting a loan of 5000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be the 1st loan taken out by Yolanda from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve her family's general living conditions. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 38 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase products to sell

loans.name: Violeta

texts.en:
Goals are nothing unless one takes the effort to meet them. Violeta T., 57, knows this, and gives her best to accomplish the goals she has set for her and her family. She finished her high school studies and is married to Esteban T., 58, a jeepney driver. They have been blessed with one child,  who is currently in the third year level of her high school education.  Together, they live in  Paroloa, Tondo, Manila.

Violeta helps her husband earn a living by managing a banana-que stand where she also sells packed meals which she cooks herself. Banana-que stands are popular in many different corners of Manila. Banana-que is a delicious saba banana, deep fried and coated with caramelized brown sugar.  This is one of the best Filipino comfort foods.  

Violeta earns income by buying a variety of ripe bananas and selling them piece by piece with a minimum mark up.  Early in the morning, she also cooks the viands which are commonly used in Filipino breakfasts, packs them into Php 15-20 packets, and sells them to her neighbors and patrons in the community.  With these businesses, she is able to earn a minimum of Php 700.

To help her continue the operations of her business, she would like to request a loan for Php 8,000. She will use this fund to buy more goods and raw materials needed for her banana-que stand and packed meals business. With the help of this loan, she will be able to continue her business and increase her earning capacity as a micro entrepreneur.

Violeta learns the value of improving one’s business, and thus works to innovate hers. She does not emphasize any problem she encounters, but rather focuses on its solution. Goals cannot be met simply by identifying the problem, but by acting on them. One of the most important goal she has in mind is to support her child until college graduation, at which point she will feel most fulfilled.

As CCT community partner, she faithfully attends to their weekly fellowship* meeting where she can also draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God she received. 

*All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay microfinance loans.

loans.use: To purchase raw ingredients for food vending business

loans.name: Nozanin

texts.ru: Мирватаниева Нозанин проживает в районе Дж. Руми. Ей 25 лет. Вдова, имеет двоих детей. Образование среднее. Живет вместе с родителями и братом. После смерти мужа она была вынуждена работать, и обеспечивать детей. Сейчас Нозанин работает официанткой в столовой своего брата. В этой области уже два года. Кредит просит для расширения бизнеса. Она хочет открыть свою собственную столовую.
texts.en: M. Nozanin lives in the J. Rumy region. She's twenty-five years old, widowed and has two children. She has a high school level of education and lives with her family. She had to support her family after her brothers' death. She's been working as a waitress in her brother's cafe for the past two years. She's asking for a loan in order to open and expand her own cafe.

loans.use: To expand her business

loans.name: Maribel

texts.en:
Maribel T., 30, is single, a college graduate and lives in Parola, a part of Tondo that is a district of Manila. She is an entrepreneur with a knack for multitasking who is accomplished in establishing businesses. Her training with CCT as a community partner has enabled her to be successful in business.

Being in the direct-sales business, Maribel has developed the skill to choose quality products and deal with people in the neighborhood so as to turn them into regular customers. She sells shirts, pants, bags, shoes, cosmetics, fashion accessories and jewelry that suit the tastes of her friends and business connections. She earns an income by availing herself of discounts from product catalogs and then selling these items at their regular price to her customers. At the end of the month, she is able to earn a minimum net income of around 10,000 PHP.

To help her continue operation of her business, she is requesting a 27,000 PHP loan. She plans to use this loan to purchase items ordered in advance by her customers. She will also purchase items that are usually ordered by her patrons so that she will be ready to offer them to her clients. By doing this, Maribel believes that she will be able to increase her earning capacity as a micro-entrepreneur.

Sure enough, Maribel does have her share of customers who do not pay on time. Nevertheless, she still prays that she will be able to collect their payments. She dreams of having her house renovated soon and that her business will continue to flourish so she can be of help to her family and relatives.

All CCT community partners and clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of fifteen to thirty community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital and pay microfinance loans. As a CCT community partner, Maribel faithfully attends CCT’s weekly fellowship meeting where she can also draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God she receives.

loans.use: To purchase items ordered in advance by her customers

loans.name: Lolita

texts.en:
Lolita A. is 47, single and is a resident of Parola, a part of Tondo, which is a district of Manila. Lolita is raising her elementary-grade nephew. She struggles and works hard for their daily needs. She is currently saving up for her nephew’s college education. Being a high school undergraduate herself, she knows that there is nothing as important as an education for her nephew.

Lolita sells garlic and onions, staples of Filipino cuisine. Every dish must contain either one or both of these. Lolita purchases wholesale onions and garlic, cleans and peels them, repackages them into 10 PHP or 5 PHP bags and then sells them to the local markets and the immediate community. She also sells plastic wares in the market. With these businesses, she is able to raise at least a minimum of 1,000 PHP gross in sales every day.

Lolita is requesting a 8,000 PHP loan that she will use to buy more garlic and onions to expand her inventory. She expects a boost in her income as she expands her business.

Lolita dreams of being able to send her nephew to college through the profits she earns from her work. She also prays for good health for them both.

All CCT community partners and clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of fifteen to thirty community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital and make microfinance loan payments. Lolita faithfully meets with her co-fellowship members every week to share stories of her work. This is also a venue where she can draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God she receives.

loans.use: To buy more garlic and onions

loans.name: Hanny

texts.en:
Hanny is a married woman with four children, three of whom attend school while one is still too young for school. She lives in a rental house that has electricity but not piped water. Her greatest monthly expenses are rent bills and school fees. 

She has been operating a charcoal selling business for the past three years, selling from home to her neighbours and passersby. Hanny faces a major challenge in the seasonality of demands and the high cost of transporting charcoal. She hopes to expand and establish another charcoal shop in the future.

With this loan for Kshs 20,000, she wants to purchase sacks of charcoal for resale. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: To purchase charcoal for resale

loans.name: Yuliani

texts.en:
Yuliani is a 43-year-old, friendly woman. She is married and has two children: Ni Wayan, 18 years old; and Komal, 7 years old. Both of them are at school.

Yuliani’s husband is only a low-level employee who earns a small income on a monthly basis. As a wife, Yuliani also feels responsible to support her husband in meeting their family needs. Moreover, her second child Komal is having problems with his digestive system. Yuliani has to spend a lot of money for Komal’s treatment and sometimes she has to borrow money from her relatives for the treatment. This situation drove Yuliani to do something to generate additional income for her family. 

She used her little money as capital to initiate her business. She sells clothes that she orders from Java (the western part of Indonesia). She prefers to order her business stock from Java because of the cheaper price. Due to the limited capital that she had, she could only have limited stock to sell and as a result, she could only generate a small income. 

Yuliani really wants to improve her business by adding more clothes and other items to sell. She is requesting a loan of IDR 10,000,000 from TLM. She believes that the loan will help her to generate better income.

loans.use: To buy more clothes and other items to sell

loans.name: Godiano

texts.en:
Godiano is a 41-year-old, married man with five children. He owns a house in Kasese, Uganda. He has been dealing in the motor vehicle business for the last eight years, during which time he was driving other people’s vehicles and now he drives his own. His hardship is high fuel prices and his vision is to have three motor vehicles plus educating his children.

Godiano needs the loan to buy an engine for his taxi.

loans.use: Buying an engine for the motor vehicle

loans.name: Mwanatumu

texts.en:
Mwanatumu is a married woman with nine children, five of whom attend school while the others have graduated from school. She owns a house that has neither electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expenses are food and school fees for her children. 

She has operated a cashew nut and coconut business for the past seven years, selling from home to her neighbors and passersby. Mwanatumu faces a major challenge of seasonality because during the dry summer season, the availability of cashew nuts for sale is lower. She hopes to expand and supply as a wholesaler in the future.

With the 50,000 Kenyan shillings, she wants to purchase sacks of coconuts, cashew nuts and fruits for sale. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to eradicate poverty and educate her children.

loans.use: To purchase sacks of coconuts, cashew nuts and fruits for sale

loans.name: Edson

texts.en: Edson is a thirty-nine-year-old married man with seven children who owns a house in Kasese, Uganda. He has run a retail shop for the last four years, which he started with capital of 500,000 shillings and grew to 4,000,000 shillings. He says his hardship is that he has many debtors, and that vision is to have a wholesale business and to be able to educate his children.  Edson intends to use the proceeds from this loan to buy inventory such as rice, sugar and salt.

loans.use: To buy inventory such as rice, sugar, and salt.

loans.name: Luiscita

texts.en:
Luiscita is 31 years old and lives in the town of San Francisco, Agusan Del Sur. She is married and has three children aged six, three, and seven months. To make a living, Luiscita plants, grows, and harvests rice for sale. Luiscita has been a farmer for over five years.

Luiscita joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Luiscita is requesting a new loan of 4,000 Philippine pesos, which will be used to purchase seed, fertilizer and other farm inputs. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Luiscita from CEVI. She plans to use any additional revenue generated from her enterprise to improve her business.

About CEVI:

Community Economic Ventures, Inc (CEVI) has increased its portfolio significantly over the recent years.  Based in Bohol, they have numerous branches throughout the Philippines.  In 2009, CEVI was awarded a CGAP silver award for transparency in social performance monitoring.  CEVI not only provides credit for its clients but additionally savings, insurance, and training which are provided through regular cluster group meetings.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase seed, fertilizer and other farm inputs.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase a fishing net.

loans.name: Marilou

texts.en:
30-year-old Marilou lives in the town of San Francisco, Agusan Del Sur. She is married and has five young children. Her eldest child is nine years old, while the youngest is only three months old. Marilou has been a farmer for five years now. She plants and harvests rice, and then sells it at market. Marilou works hard to improve her family's living conditions. Her children's education is a top priority of hers.

Marilou joined CEVI to gain access to financial services with the hopes of improving her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Marilou is requesting a loan of 4,000 Philippine pesos which will be used to purchase fertilizers and seeds, and this will be the first loan she has taken out from CEVI. She plans to use any additional revenue generated from her business to pay for her children's tuition fees.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizer and seed.

loans.name: Marilyn

texts.en:
34-year-old Marilyn lives in the town of San Francisco, Agusan Del Sur with her family. She is married and has three children aged 15, 13, and six. All of her kids go to school. To make a living, Marilyn plants and harvests rice for sale. Marilyn wishes to have a more stable business.

Marilyn joined CEVI to gain access to financial services with the hopes of improving her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. This 4,000 Philippine peso loan is Marilyn's first loan from CEVI, and she intends to use the proceeds to purchase seed, fertilizer and other farm inputs. She plans to use any additional revenue generated from the business to improve her family's living conditions.

loans.use: To purchase seed, fertilizer and other farm inputs

loans.name: Renilda

texts.en:
Renilda is 39 years old and from the town of San Francisco. She is married and has no children yet. To make a living, Renilda plants and harvests rice for sale. Renilda works hard to build her business and save for the future.

Renilda joined Kiva field partner CEVI to gain access to financial services with the hopes of improving her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Renilda is requesting her first loan, for 4,000 Philippine pesos, with which she intends to buy seed, fertilizer, and medicine.  She plans to use any additional revenue generated from her enterprise to improve her business.

loans.use: To buy seed, fertilizer, and medicine.

loans.name: Maimuna

texts.en:
Maimuna is a married woman with five children.  Four of her children have graduated from school, and one still attends school. She owns a house that neither has electricity nor plumbing. Her greatest monthly expense is food for her family.

For the past three years, she has been making mahamri (dumplings) for sale. She sells the dumplings from home to her neighbors and passersby. Maimuna says she a major challenge she faces in doing business is the high cost of transporting charcoal. She hopes to expand her business in the future.

With the proceeds from this 20,000 Kenyan shilling loan, Maimuna wants to purchase wheat flour and cooking oil, and wants to buy sacks of charcoal in order to start selling charcoal. She decided to join Kiva field partner Yehu to access loans with the hopes of improving her business.

loans.use: To purchase wheat flour and cooking oil, and to buy sacks of charcoal in order to start a charcoal selling business.

loans.name: Riza

texts.en:
Riza G. is from the town of San Francisco. She is 45 years old, married and has eight children. Her eldest child is 18 years old while the youngest is only seven. To make a living, Riza plants and harvests rice for sale. Riza has been farming for five years now. She is hoping for a better harvest.

Riza joined CEVI to gain access to financial services with the hopes of improving her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Riza is requesting her first loan of 4,000 Philippine pesos from Kiva field partner CEVI, with which she intends to purchase fertilizer and other farm inputs. She plans to use any additional revenue generated from her enterprise to pay for her children's tuition fees. 

About CEVI:

Community Economic Ventures, Inc (CEVI) has increased its portfolio significantly over the recent years.  Based in Bohol, they have numerous branches throughout the Philippines.  In 2009, CEVI was awarded a CGAP silver award for transparency in social performance monitoring.  CEVI not only provides credit for its clients but additionally savings, insurance, and training which are provided through regular cluster group meetings.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizer and other farm inputs.

loans.name: Mourk

texts.en:
From Kompong Thom province, Mourk V. has been making Khmer noodles at home since 2001. She always receives a lot of orders from her regular clients; she also has new clients who place orders for noodles to resell at the busy market. She earns an income of approximately $2 per day to support the family.

She has a life partner in her husband who works cultivating the rice crop as well as trading cows. He often goes around the community to buy his neighbors’ cows at a reasonable prices, and will then sell them at a profit. Now, Mourk V.’s husband wishes to increase his animal sales by purchasing a few cows,  but he doesn’t have enough capital to do it yet. That is the reason why Mourk V. would like to request a loan from Kiva.

loans.use: To purchase a few cows for resale

loans.name: Teresita

texts.en:
Teresita D. is from the town of San Francisco. She is 51 years old, married and has five children. Two of her children still go to school. To make a living, Teresita plants and harvests rice for sale. Teresita hopes to be able to earn enough money to sustain her children's education, especially now that tuition fees are increasing every year.

Teresita joined Kiva field partner CEVI to gain access to financial services with the hopes of improving her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Teresita is requesting her first loan of 4,000 Philippine pesos, with which she intends to buy farm inputs like seed and fertilizer. She plans to use any additional revenue generated from her enterprise to improve her business. 

About CEVI:

Community Economic Ventures, Inc (CEVI) has increased its portfolio significantly over the recent years.  Based in Bohol, they have numerous branches throughout the Philippines.  In 2009, CEVI was awarded a CGAP silver award for transparency in social performance monitoring.  CEVI not only provides credit for its clients but additionally savings, insurance, and training which are provided through regular cluster group meetings.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To buy farm inputs like seed and fertilizer.

loans.name: Michael Wacira

texts.en:
Since 2004, Michael has been running a clinical laboratory in Nairobi town centre. He earns a profit of 25,500 Kenyan shillings (KES) per month. He is 36 years old, married to Gilian Wambui and they have two children. He describes himself as hardworking. 

Michael was introduced to KADET by an old member, and he is applying for a second loan of 50,000 KES. He plans to use the entire amount to buy one microscope which will help him serve his customers well. He plans to plough the anticipated profit back into the business. In the future he hopes to open a hospital.

loans.use: To buy a microscope

loans.name: Baatarsuren

texts.en:
Baatarsuren, 30, lives with his wife and his newly born son in Ulaanbaatar, the capital of Mongolia. They live in a ger, which is a Mongolian nomadic housing tent, on the outskirts of the city.  He is requesting a loan of 3,500,000 Mongolian tugrik (MNT) to buy more winter clothing to sell at his outdoor stall at the market. 	

Baatarsuren started his business trading clothing in the year 2000 at Narantuul, a big outdoor market, and has continued to operate his business successfully. While he says his family has a decent standard of living, he wants to expand his business further and increase his profit to better support his family.

loans.use: To buy more winter clothing.

loans.name: Virginia's Group

texts.en:
Virginia G. is from the village of Linglingay, Cauayan City, Isabela. She is 30 years old. Virginia is the leader of a 8-member group loan offered by ASKI. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults.

Virginia is married and has 1 infant-aged child. To make a living, Virginia runs a general store, where she sells food and daily use products in the local community. Virginia has been engaged in her business for over 3 years and earns approximately 3000 PHP a month.

Virginia joined ASKI this year to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Virginia is requesting her first loan, for 7000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional inventory and as working capital. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 38 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fishers and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partners to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional inventory

loans.name: Batzaya

texts.en:
Batzaya, 31, lives with her husband in Ulaanbaatar, the capital of Mongolia. They live in a ger, which is a Mongolian nomadic housing tent, on the outskirts of the city. 

Batzaya started her retail trading business in 1998. Now she sells clothing at a local market. Her husband owns a car which he sometimes uses as a taxi in order to support his wife's business. Batzaya is a modest person who wants to expand her business in order to buy a house where she and her husband can live a comfortable life. She is requesting a loan of 2,500,000 MNT to purchase more clothing for her business and to increase her working capital.

loans.use: To purchase more clothing to sell

loans.name: Edward Machang'a

texts.en:
Edward Machang’a W. is 31-years-old, married to Njeri and they are blessed with two children. He has been selling computers and offers other services related to computers, like repairs, for six years. His profit margin is 7,000 Kenyan shillings (KES) per month. His business is located in Nairobi's central business district, which has a heavy concentration of offices; hence, is good for computer sales and services.

Edward was introduced to KADET by an old client and he is applying for a loan of 25,000 KES. He plans to buy spare parts for computers with 10,000 KES and one computer for 15,000 KES. He will add more stock with the profit and eventually open a big computer shop. He wants to offer his children better education.

loans.use: To buy spare parts and one computer

loans.name: Oyungerel

texts.en:
Oyungerel L. is 54, and a micro-entrepreneur. She lives with her daughter in an apartment, inherited from her mother, in Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia. As a widow, she works extremely hard to provide for the daily needs of her family. 

She graduated from the Institute of Commerce and Business in Mongolia with a concentration in retail in 1977.  Until 2004, Oyungerel worked as a retail staffer for several local companies. 

Since 2005, Oyungerel has supported her family by operating a jewelry retail stall at Narantuul, the largest outdoor market in Mongolia. She began her business by distributing silver rings, necklaces, earrings and bracelets to local customers. Now her working capital is about 1.5 million MNT and its turnover is twice a month. She purchases her products from a Turkish jewelry wholesale supplier. 

Her moderate revenue supports her standard of living, though she would like to buy her own indoor jewelry store because the outdoor stall is difficult to work at due to weather conditions.  She is requesting a 500,000 MNT loan to invest in working capital before the Mongolian Lunar New Year holiday.  She believes that this loan and future loans will help her achieve her goal.  

Oyungerel’s biggest dream is to see her daughter to be successful in life and to help provide that opportunity.

loans.use: To purchase silver rings, necklaces, earrings and bracelets

loans.name: Byambanorov

texts.en:
Byambanorov, 37, lives with her husband and two children in Ulaanbaatar, the capital of Mongolia. Her daughter attends a local secondary school and her son goes to kindergarten. They live in a ger, a Mongolian nomadic housing tent, in someone's backyard on the outskirts of the city.

Byambanorov sells meat at a local market, and started her business in 2006. Her business was running successfully until their house burnt down in 2009.  Her family's living standard is now below average because of that unfortunate fire, however they are trying very hard to rebuild their lives. Byambanorov is a very hardworking and active person whose family needs a house on their own land. She is requesting a loan of 3,500,000 Mongolian tugriks (MNT) to purchase more meat for her business during the busy time of Tsagaan Sar, the Mongolian traditional New Year.

loans.use: To purchase more meat

loans.name: Bobby

texts.en:
Bobby M. is a rice grower from the community of Trinidad, Bohol. He is blessed with four children, and all of them are still in school.  He has been growing rice since 2005. It is his hope that he will be able to continue his business and provide for his family's needs.

His major challenge as a farmer is during typhoon season, when floods are not uncommon. Now, he wants to buy farm inputs.  He intends to use this 6,000 Philippine peso loan to buy seeds and pay the laborers who work for him on his farm.

loans.use: To buy seeds and pay farm laborers.

loans.name: Gemma

texts.en:
Gemma A. is 48 years old, lives in Trinidad, Bohol, and has five children who are still studying in school.  She owns a videoke machine (karaoke machine) which is used for entertainment.  When there are special gatherings, everyone sings through it.  Gemma makes money from the machine by renting it out.

Gemma intends to use this 8,000 Philippine peso (PHP) loan to expand her business. She is also interested in exploring other possible income-generating activities with the hopes of increasing her current earnings.

loans.use: To invest in expanding the business

loans.name: Maricel

texts.en:
Maricel A. is a pig grower from the community of Trinidad, Bohol.  She started her business in 1998.  Her love for her husband motivated her to start this business.  It is her great joy that she has been able to help meet all of her family's needs.

She would like to apply a loan of 6,000 PHP from Community Economic Ventures Inc.  The loan will help her buy piglets and feed.  Aside from that, she also plans to try other business opportunities that will help her augment her income.

Maricel is 28 years old.  She wanted to save money because soon, when she has a baby, she will be confident that she can support all her family's needs.

loans.use: To buy piglets and feed.

loans.name: Enhbayar

texts.en:
Enhbayar, 54, is married and lives with his wife and three daughters in Ulaanbaatar, the capital of Mongolia.  They live in a ger, which is a Mongolian nomadic housing tent.  His oldest daughter and wife help his business while his two younger daughters attend University.  

He started a woodcraft and car repair service businesses in 1999.  He makes wood products which his wife sells at Narantuul, the biggest outdoor market in Ulaanbaatar.  By operating his business he supports his family and pays for the studies of his daughters.  Their living situation is improving little by little.  They have their own land where someday they dream of building a house.  

Enhbayar is a hardworking and humble man who says that he is trying to provide his daughters with an opportunity to get a good education.  He is requesting a loan of 3,000,000 MNT to purchase more wood and material for his woodcraft business.

loans.use: To purchase more wood and material.

loans.name: Marisol

texts.en:
Marisol Entina owns and manages a small sari-sari store in Trinidad Bohol. She desires to own a bigger store someday. It is her hope that she will be able to stand a grocery store and earn a higher income for her family.

She would like to apply a loan of PhP 8,000. Receiving this amount will be helpful in buying additional merchandise to resell. In that way, she will be able to offer her customers a variety of products that they will really enjoy.

Marisol is 28 years old with a 1-year old child. Most of her business income goes towards the family basic needs while the rest goes back to her business.

loans.use: to buy additional merchandise to resell

loans.name: Paulus

texts.en:
Paulus is a-46-year old man who is married to Yuke. They have been blessed with 6 children. They are:  Anggi, a 17 year old senior high school student; Marten, a 15 year old junior high school student; Ningsih, a 13 year old junior high school student; Eka, 9 years old elementary school student; Yessy, who is aged 4 years and Yastin who is 2 years old.
 
Paulus is a man who does not easily give up. Although many problems have happened in his life, he always deals with positive thoughts. To make a living, Paulus runs a small kiosk business. This is the main income source for his family. Paulus realizes that the income generated from his kiosk is limited as a result of the limited capital that he has. As a responsible father, Paulus wants to provide his children with access to school. He wants them to have a bright future. 

Paulus wanted to improve his kiosk but he did not have enough capital to do it. He ever tried to borrow from a cooperative with daily repayment. But there was no improvement in his business as the profit was used to pay the installments. Paulus then heard about TLM’s individual lending program and got interested in joining the program due to the monthly repayment system and achievable interest rate. He is requesting a loan of IDR 3,000,000 from TLM. He plans to use the loan to buy more stocks to sell at his kiosk.

loans.use: To purchase more items to sell at his kiosk

loans.name: Milagros

texts.en:
Milagros F., 44 years old is engaged into rice production business. She started her business in 2001. She hopes that she will be able to own a bigger farm someday and continue to provide her family the things that they need.

Her business challenges is that she doesn’t have enough money to buy the farm inputs.  Also, seeds and fertilizers are quite expensive. Receiving a loan will help her go on with her business. It is her hope that she will be able to have an abundant harvest.

Milagros is 44 years old and a mother of two children.

loans.use: to buy farm supplies like seeds and fertilizer

loans.name: Myrna

texts.en:
Myrna M., 38 years old is a gasoline vendor in the town of Trinidad Bohol. She has been doing this business since 2008. The income, which she was able to generate, is very helpful in sending her children to school and in buying the family basic needs. 

At the moment, she wants to apply a loan of Php 6,000 from Community Economic Ventures Inc. She will use the loan to buy more gasoline to resell. She also plans of looking for some other income opportunities where she could increase her current earnings.

Myrna is 38 years old and has four children that are studying in school.

loans.use: to buy more gasoline to resell

loans.name: Prima

texts.en:
Prima  B., 56 years old is a rice grower from the community of Trinidad, Bohol. She started her business last 2001. She desired of having a bigger farm in the future. She wished that she would be able to support the needs of her family even if she as she is getting older.

She would like to apply a loan of PhP 8,000 from CEVI. She will use the funds to buy farm supplies like seeds and fertilizer.  In this way, she will be able to grow her harvest. The loan will also help improve her business and her family.

Prima enjoys the micro insurance program of CEVI and the company of other entrepreneurs in their loan association.

loans.use: to buy farm supplies like seeds and fertilizer

loans.name: Sabati Group

texts.fr:
Les sept femmes du groupe Sabati, toutes mariées, ont en moyenne 41 ans, 3 enfants et vivent toutes dans des familles traditionnelles élargies dans le village de Dioni, préfecture de Barouéli, Région de Ségou (quatrième région  administrative de la république du Mali).
Elles se sont connues à travers des liens de parenté et font le commerce de poissons, de condiments et d’arachide.                                                                                     
Les femmes du groupe Sabati sont à leur troisième prêt solidaire. 
ASSAN T. compte acheter des poissons fumés aussi bien que frais avec les revendeurs de Konobougou et cela chaque semaine. Elle revend sur place à Konobougou et en cas de mévente le reste sera vendu au village, au comptant et à crédit, à une clientèle composée de femmes et d’hommes.
Elle envisage réaliser un bénéfice moyen mensuel de 15 000F CFA qui sera utilisé pour payer les échéances du prêt, une partie pour prendre en charge les dépenses relatives à la santé,  à la nourriture,  aux frais scolaires de ses enfants et le reste sera  réinvesti dans les activités.
texts.en:
The seven women in the group Sabati are all married; their average age is 41 years old and they each have an average of three children. They all live in traditional extended families in the town of Diono, within the prefecture of Barouéli, which is in the region of Ségou (the fourth administrative region of the Republic of Mali).
They know each other through family connections and their business is selling fish, condiments and ground nuts. The women of the group Sabati are requesting their third group loan.
Assan T. will purchase smoked and fresh fish from the vendors in Konobougou every week.She will re-sell these goods in Konobougou and, when necessary, will sell the remaining stock in her town.She will sell her goods for cash, or credit to a customer base of men and women. She expects to earn a monthly profit of 15,000 CFA, which she will use to repay her loan. She will use part of her earnings to help pay for medical expenses, food and her children's school tuition. She will re-invest the rest of her earnings in her business.

loans.use: To purchase fish

loans.name: Rufina

texts.en:
Rufina M., 53 years old is a rice grower from Trinidad, Bohol. He has been growing rice since 2001. Her hope is that, she will be able to own a bigger farm and provide her family with all the things that they need. 

Her current challenge is  that she needs additional capitalization for her business. The farm supplies are also expensive in the market. Getting a loan from CEVI will help her buy seeds and pay the laborers that work for her farm.

Rufina enjoys biblical reflection during loan meetings and fellowship with other borrowers.

loans.use: to buy seeds and pay the laborers

loans.name: Salmun

texts.en:
Salmun is a 32 year old man. He works as a scrap metal collector. He has been running this business for almost 3 years, since his first son started to attend school. He used to run a motor-taxi business, but the income was unstable and sometimes wasn’t sufficient to meet his family needs. Salmun then tried to find another way to earn more income. The scrap metal business became the one option for him to generate income. He worked for his brother who had the capital to buy the scrap metal. He bought the scrap metal from the salvagers. The scrap metal will then be resold. Salmun’s income was dependent on the profit of his brother. 

Salmun is the father of 3 children, namely: Ananda, who is 9 years old; Raju, who is 8 years old and Pink, who is 2 years old. As a father, he wants to provide a good life for his wife and children. Salmun is grateful for the business has helped him in meeting his family needs even though the income was not so much. 

Salmun wants to improve his income and this is the reason why he initiated his own business using his own capital. The challenge for Salmun in running the business is the capital limitation. He is now requesting a loan from TLM amounting to IDR 4,000,000. He plans to use the loan to buy more scrap metal to be sold. He hopes that the loan can support him in improving his business.

loans.use: To purchase more scrap metal to be resold

loans.name: Yeredeme Group

texts.fr:
Les femmes du groupe Yeredeme, toutes mariées, ont en moyenne 35 ans, 3 enfants et vivent toutes dans des familles traditionnelles élargies dans le village de Wela, sous-préfecture de Konobougou ; Région de Ségou (quatrième région  administrative de la république du Mali).
Elles se sont connues à travers des liens de parenté, de voisinage et d’amitié. Elles font le commerce de tubercules et des gâteaux.                                                                                     
Les femmes du groupe Yeredeme sont à leur premier prêt solidaire qui sera utilisé pour acheter des tubercules et de la farine de blé.                                                                          
HAYA C. s’approvisionne en tubercules (igname, patates, et manioc etc.) avec les grossistes de Konobougou pendant les jours de foires. Elle effectue ses ventes sur place dans le marché de Konobougou, au comptant et à crédit, à une clientèle composée de femmes et d’hommes.
Elle envisage réaliser un bénéfice moyen mensuel de 10 000F CFA qui sera utilisé pour payer les échéances du prêt, les frais de contributions des différentes cérémonies civiles, certaine dépenses familiales et le reste sera  réinvesti dans son activité de commerce de tubercules.
texts.en:
The women of the Yeredeme group, all married, are on average 35 years old with 3 children each and all live in large traditional families in the village of Wela.  Wela is a sub-prefecture of Konobougou, in the region of  Ségou (the fourth administrative region of the Republic of Mali).  They know each other as fellow parents, neighbors, and friends.  They are in the business of selling tubers and cakes.

The women of the Yeredeme group are requesting their first group loan which will be used to buy tubers and wheat flour.

Haya C. stocks up on tubers (yams, potatoes, cassava) with the grocers of Konobougou on market days.  She carries out her sales in a stall in the market of Konobougou, accepting cash and credit, serving a clientele made up of both women and men.  She foresees earning a monthly profit of 10,000 FCFA which will be used to pay the loan installments, contribute more money to various civil ceremonies, cover certain family expenses, and the remainder will be reinvested in their tuber-selling business.

loans.use: Buying tubers

loans.name: Benkan Group

texts.fr:
Les femmes du groupe Benkan, toutes mariées, ont en moyenne 44 ans, 3 enfants et vivent toutes dans des familles traditionnelles élargies dans le village de Marka-Coungo, sous préfecture de Fana ; Région de Koulikoro (deuxième région  administrative de la république du Mali).
Elles se sont connues à travers des liens de parenté, de voisinage et d’amitiés. Elles font le commerce des habits, de gâteaux et du lait.                                                                                                                                                      
Les femmes du groupe Benkan sont à leur septième prêt solidaire qui sera utilisé pour acheter des pagnes wax, de la farine de blé et du lait.                                                                             
BATA D., la présidente du groupe,  compte acheter 100 pièces de pagnes wax avec les grossistes au marché de Bamako presque chaque mois. Elle revend au marché et à domicile, au comptant et à crédit, à une clientèle composée de femmes et d’hommes.
Elle envisage réaliser un bénéfice moyen mensuel de 30 000F CFA qui sera utilisé pour payer les échéances du prêt, une partie pour prendre en charge les dépenses relatives à la santé,  à la nourriture,  aux frais scolaires et le reste sera  réinvesti dans les activités.
texts.en:
The women of the Benkan group, all married, are on average 44 years old with three children each, and all live in large traditional families in the village of Marka-Coungo, a sub-prefecture of Fana, in the region of Koulikoro (the second administrative region of the Republic of Mali). They have known each other as fellow parents, neighbors, and friends.  They sell clothing, cakes, and milk.

The women of the Benkan group are requesting their seventh group loan, which will be used to purchase fine fabrics, flour, and milk.

Bata D., the president of the group, intends to purchase 100 lengths of fabric from the wholesale dealers at the market in Bamako nearly every month.   She resells them in the market and out of her home, for cash or credit, to a clientele made up of women and men.  She foresees earning a monthly profit of 30,000 FCFA which she will use to pay their loan installments, in part to assume health and food expenses, to cover school fees, and the remainder will be reinvested in the business.

loans.use: Purchasing fabric

loans.name: Djekafo Group

texts.fr:
Les femmes du groupe Djekafo, toutes mariées, ont en moyenne 44 ans, 3 enfants et vivent toutes dans des familles traditionnelles élargies dans le village de Marka-Coungo, sous préfecture de Fana ; Région de Koulikoro (deuxième région  administrative de la république du Mali).
Elles se sont connues à travers des liens de parenté, de voisinage et d’amitiés, elles font le commerce de tubercules, du beurre de karité, de gâteaux, de la viande et du lait.                                                                                                                                                          
Les femmes du groupe Djekafo sont à leur huitième prêt solidaire qui sera utilisé pour acheter des tubercules, du beurre de karité, de la farine de blé, de la viande et du lait.                                                                             
KAMISSA D. compte acheter 100 kg de beurre de Karité avec les revendeurs de la ville de Marka-Coungo et environnants hebdomadairement. Elle revend au marché et à domicile, au comptant et à crédit, à une clientèle composée de femmes et d’hommes.
Elle envisage réaliser un bénéfice moyen mensuel de 35.000F CFA qui sera utilisé pour payer les échéances du prêt, une partie pour prendre en charge les dépenses relatives à la santé et le reste sera  réinvesti dans les activités.
texts.en:
The women of the Djekafo group, all married, are on average 44 years old, have three children each, and live in traditional extended families in the village of Marka-Coungo, a sub-prefecture of Farna, in the region of Koulikoro (the second administrative region in the Republic of Mali).  They have known each other as fellow parents, neighbors, and friends.  They are sellers of tubers, shea butter, cakes, meat, and milk.

The women of the Djekafo group seek their eighth group loan which will be used to buy tubers, shea butter, flour, meat, and milk.

Kamissa D. intends to buy 100kg of shea butter from the resellers in the city of Marka-Coungo and its surrounding areas weekly.  She resells at the market and from her home, for cash or credit, to a clientele made up of women and men.  She foresees earning a monthly profit of 35,000 FCFA which will be used to pay the loan installments, to assume health and food expenses, and the remainder will be reinvested in the business.

loans.use: Purchasing shea butter

loans.name: Jackson

texts.en: T. Jackson is involved in agriculture and sells matooke [green plantain]. He is a hardworking man who also sells coffee to supplement his income. Jackson is 46 years old and married with four children, ages 15, 12, 8 and 4 years old. They are from Rukungiri. He works closely with his wife and this has helped so much in their family's development. He has been in business for five years, having joined after realizing that the businesses were profitable. Jackson says that he is trustworthy and this has won him many customers.

loans.use: To improve a farm by buying manure and fertilisers

loans.name: Jolidew Group

texts.fr:
Les femmes du groupe Jolidew, toutes mariées, ont en moyenne 40 ans, 4 enfants et vivent toutes dans des familles traditionnelles élargies dans le village de Marka-Coungo, sous préfecture de Fana ; Région de Koulikoro (deuxième région  administrative de la république du Mali).
Elles se sont connues à travers des liens de parenté, de voisinage et d’amitiés et font la restauration, le commerce de gâteaux et du bois de chauffe.                                                                                     
Les femmes du groupe Jolidew sont à leur neuvième prêt solidaire. 
FATOUMATA T. compte acheter, cinq chargements de charrettes en bois de chauffe auprès des producteurs de la ville et environnants. Elle revend quotidiennement aux femmes de ménage chargées de cuisine à son domicile, au comptant et à crédit.
Elle envisage réaliser un bénéfice moyen mensuel de 30.000F CFA qui sera utilisé pour payer les échéances du prêt, une partie pour prendre en charge les dépenses relatives à la santé, aux frais scolaires et le reste sera  réinvesti dans les activités.
texts.en:
