The members of the Jolidew group are all married women, on the average 40 years of age, with four children. They all live in traditional extended families in the village of Marka-Coungo, Fana Sub-prefecture, Koulikoro Region (the second administrative district of Mali).
They know each other as relatives, neighbors and friends. They cook food for sale and sell cakes and firewood. 

The Jolidew group members are on their ninth solidarity loan. Fatoumata T. plans to purchase five cartloads of firewood from producers in her town and nearby earea. She retails the firewood daily to out of her home, to housekeepers who do the cooking, for cash and on credit. She plans to achieve an average monthly income of 30,000 West African Francs, which will be used to pay off the loan and to cover costs related to healthcare and school fees, with the rest reinvested in her business.

loans.use: Purchasing firewood

loans.name: Bayanmunkh

texts.en: Mr.Bayanmunkh is 26 years old and lives with his wife and daughter in Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia. His daughter goes to kindergarten. In 2009, Bayanmunkh successfully completed a bus driver course and now he works as a bus driver for a bus transport company. Between 2006 and 2009 he used to work as a ticket collector for the same company. His wife works as a ticket collector at the moment. They own a plot of land and have a small wooden house on it. Next year they are planning to make renovations and add an extension to the house. Therefore, they are trying to increase their savings. In his spare time, Bayanmunkh operates a taxi business using his old family car to earn extra money. He wants to use this loan to replace his old car with a newer one to use as a taxi.

loans.use: To replace his old car for a newer one to use as a taxi

loans.name: Kibaroudouman Group

texts.fr:
Les femmes du groupe Kibaroudouman, toutes mariées, ont en moyenne 36 ans, 2 enfants et vivent toutes dans des familles traditionnelles élargies dans le village de Marka-coungo, sous préfecture de Fana ; Région de Koulikoro (deuxième région  administrative de la république du Mali).
Elles se sont connues à travers des liens de voisinage, de parenté et d’amitiés. Elles font le commerce des habits, du bois de chauffe, de poissons, du tiéké et du haricot.                                                                                                                                                          
Les femmes du groupe Kibaroudouman sont à leur deuxième              prêt solidaire, le premier ayant été correctement remboursé.                                                                          BATOMA D. compte acheter,  100 kg de tiéké, 30 kg de poisson frais. Elle effectue quotidiennement ses ventes au marché et à domicile, au comptant et à crédit, à une clientèle composée de consommateurs et de restauratrices.
Elle envisage réaliser un bénéfice moyen mensuel de  40 000F CFA qui sera utilisé pour payer les échéances du prêt, une partie pour prendre en charge les dépenses relatives à la santé et le reste sera  réinvesti dans les activités.
texts.en:
The women of the Kibaroudouman group are all married and are 36 years old on average with 2 children. They all live in traditional extended households in the town of Marka-coungo, in the Fana sub-prefecture of the Koulikoro region (the second administrative region in the Republic of Mali).
They know each other through neighbourhood, familial, and social relations. They sell clothing, firewood, fish, tiéké (a cassava-based food), and beans.
The women of the Kibaroudouman group are on their second solidarity (group) loan, with their first one having been repaid properly.
Batoma D., one of the group members, intends to buy 100 kg of tiéké and 30 kg of fresh fish. She makes her sales every day at the market and at home, in cash and on credit, to a clientele composed of consumers and caterers.
She envisages realizing an average monthly profit of 40,000 FCFA, which will be used to pay the loan costs and to take care of the family expenses, with the remainder being reinvested in her business.

loans.use: To buy fish and tiéké (a cassava-based food)

loans.name: Oyundorj

texts.en:
Oyundorj, 39, is married and lives with his wife and three children in Hentii province of Mongolia.  All of his three children attend a local secondary school. He began making wood products in 1994. By saving money from his woodcraft business he bought a car and started a taxi service. In 2003 he began a car repair service. In the beginning he started his business by using his own working capital and from 1999 he became our customer to access loans from our bank. 

With the profit that he made from his business, he enlarged his house by 36 square meters. Thanks to his effort and experience of several years, he now has regular customers and his income is increasing as well.  His wife helps him to purchase necessary spare parts and maintenance. 

Oyundorj is a hardworking, modest and honest person whose ultimate goal is to open his own workshop. He says " I am not an engineer but I like to fix and maintain machines and I have been working in this field for many years. I had to work outside in the cold weather. Now I want to open my own workshop and create new jobs." He is requesting a loan of 3,200,000 MNT to construct a building for his future workshop.

loans.use: To build a building

loans.name: Nièta Group

texts.fr:
Les femmes du groupe Nièta, toutes mariées, ont en moyenne 44  ans, 3 enfants et vivent toutes dans des familles traditionnelles élargies dans le village de Marka-Coungo, sous préfecture de Fana ; Région de Koulikoro (deuxième région  administrative de la république du Mali).
Elles se sont connues à travers des liens de voisinage, de parenté et d’amitié. Elles font le commerce de lait, d’habillements, des poissons et du tiéké.                                                                                     
Les femmes du groupe Nieta sont à leur neuvième prêt solidaire qui sera utilisé pour acheter du lait, des habits, des poissons et du tiéké.                                                                          
KOUDE S. compte acheter, 100 litres de lait frais et 100litres de lait caillé avec les bergers de la ville et environnants. Elle revend au comptant et à crédit, à une clientèle composée de routiers.
Elle envisage réaliser un bénéfice moyen mensuel de 50.000F CFA qui sera utilisé pour payer les échéances du prêt, une partie pour prendre en charge les dépenses relatives à la santé,  à la nourriture et le reste sera  réinvesti dans les activités.
texts.en:
The women of the Nièta group, all married, are 44 years old on average with 3 children and live in traditional extended households in the town of Marka-Coungo, in the Fana sub-prefecture of the Koulikoro Region (the second administrative region in the Republic of Mali).
The know each other through neighbourhood, familial, and social relations. They sell milk, clothing, fish, and tiéké (a cassava-based food).
The women of the Nièta group are on their ninth solidarity (group) loan, which will be used to buy milk, clothing, fish, and tiéké.
Koude S., one of the group members, intends to buy 100 litres of fresh milk and 100 litres of curds from the herders in town and in the surroundings. She re-sells her goods in cash and on credit to a clientele composed of truck drivers.
She envisages realizing an average monthly profit of 50,000 FCFA, a portion of which will be used to repay the loan costs and take care of the family's health and food expenses, with the remainder being reinvested in her business.

loans.use: To buy milk

loans.name: Beatrice Wanjiru

texts.en:
Beatrice Wanjiru M. lives in Kariobangi estate. She is 43 years old and married with two children. She has been selling secondhand shoes at the busy Gikomba open-air market in Nairobi for eight years and earns a good income. 

She was introduced to KADET LTD by a member of KADET.  She is applying for her first loan of KES 80,000 from KADET. She plans to use the loan amount to buy seven bales of shoes, pay rent for the market stall and pay transport.

She plans to use the profit to pay school fees for her children, and add more stock of shoes. In the future she desires to grow her business.

loans.use: To buy shoes to sell and pay rent.

loans.name: Sabougnouman Group

texts.fr:
Les femmes du groupe Sabougnouman, toutes mariées, ont en moyenne 43 ans, 3 enfants et vivent toutes dans des familles traditionnelles élargies dans le village de Marka-Coungo, sous préfecture de Fana ; Région de Koulikoro (deuxième région  administrative de la république du Mali).
Elles se sont connues à travers des liens de parenté, de voisinage, et d’amitiés. Elles font le commerce de condiments alimentaires, des poissons fumés, du lait, des habillements, des articles divers de boutique et sont                                                                                                                                                      à leur neuvième prêt solidaire qui sera utilisé pour acheter des condiments alimentaires, des poissons fumés, du lait, des habillements et des articles divers de boutique.                                                                           DOUNAMBA C. compte acheter 40kg de poissons fumés avec les grossistes. Elle effectue quotidiennement ses ventes sur place à domicile et au marché de Marka-Coungo, au comptant et à crédit, à une clientèle composée de femmes et d’hommes.
Elle envisage réaliser un bénéfice moyen mensuel de 22.500F CFA qui sera utilisé pour payer les échéances du prêt, une partie pour prendre en charge les dépenses relatives à la santé,  à la nourriture,  aux frais scolaires et le reste sera  réinvesti dans les activités.
texts.en:
The women of the Sabougnouman group, all married, are 43 years old on average with 3 children and live in traditional extended households in the town of Marka-Coungo in the Fana sub-prefecture of the Koulikoro region (the second administrative region in the Republic of Mali).
They know each other through familial, neighbourhood, and social relations. They sell food condiments, smoked fish, milk, clothing, and various store items, and are on their ninth solidarity (group) loan, which will be used to buy these items.
Dounamba C., one of the group members, intends to buy 40 kg of smoked fish from wholesalers. She makes her sales every day at her home and at the market in Marka-Coungo, in cash and on credit, to a clientele composed of women and men.
She foresees realizing an average monthly profit of 22,500 FCFA, some of which will be used to pay the loan costs and to take care of the family's health, food, and schooling costs, with the remainder being reinvested in her business.

loans.use: To buy smoked fish

loans.name: Narantsetseg

texts.en:
Narantsetseg, 38, is married and lives with her husband and two sons in Hentii province of Mongolia. Her husband is unemployed and both sons attend a local secondary school. In 2000 Naraantsetseg began to sell handmade boots. From 2007 she began her clothing trading business where she rents a stall at a local market. She has been operating her business successfully and as a result has many regular customers. Her husband helps her with the purchases. 

She is planning to run her business for the long term and wishes to expand it more. She says"" As a main source of our family income, I would like to expand my business more"". She is a sociable and active person. She is requesting a loan of 1,000,000 MNT to purchase more clothing to sell during the busy time of Tsagaan Sar, the Mongolian New Year.

loans.use: To purchase more clothing

loans.name: Daisy

texts.en:
42-year-old Daisy E. is from the town of San Francisco. She is married and has 4 children aged 21, 19, 17 and 15. To make a living, Daisy owns & operates a business venture in the agriculture sector raising crops. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from planting and harvesting rice for sale. Like any other mother, Daisy only wants the best for her children. She does her best to keep her family happy and healthy.

Daisy joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Daisy is requesting a new loan of 4000 PHP which will be used to buy fertilizers, medicines and seeds. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Daisy from CEVI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to pay for her children's tuition fees. 

About CEVI:

Community Economic Ventures, Inc (CEVI) has increased its portfolio significantly over the recent years.  Based in Bohol, they have numerous branches throughout the Philippines.  In 2009, CEVI was awarded a CGAP silver award for transparency in social performance monitoring.  CEVI not only provides credit for its clients but additionally savings, insurance, and training which are provided through regular cluster group meetings.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to buy fertilizer, medicines and seeds

loans.name: Zagdsambuu

texts.en:
Zagdsambuu, 31, is married and lives with his wife and two year old daughter in Songino-Hairhan district of Ulaanbaatar, a capital of Mongolia.  He had an employment contract between Mongolia and South Korea which allowed him to gain experience working in Korea.  

When he returned to his home country, he started a food trading business.  He opened a grocery store where his wife helps him operate the food shop. Zagdsaambuu mostly does the food purchasing for the store and also drives a taxi.  While working in Korea, he gained a lot experience about how to operate a business as well as financial responsibility.  He wants to enlarge his current store by next year.  He is a hardworking man with a lot of initiative.  He is requesting a loan of 2,500,000 MNT so he can purchase more grocery products for his business since he now lacks adequate working capital.

loans.use: To purchase more grocery products

loans.name: Lady Jane

texts.en:
Lady Jane C. is from the town of San Francisco.  She is 31 years old.  Lady Jane is married and has 4 children ages 11, 7, 5 and 2 years old.  To make a living, Lady Jane owns and operates a business venture in the agriculture sector raising crops.  While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from planting and harvesting rice for sale.  Lady Jane has been engaged in her business for over 4 years.

Lady Jane joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities.  Lady Jane is requesting a new loan of 4,000 PHP which will be used to purchase fertilizers such as manure.  This loan will be the first loan taken out by Lady Jane from CEVI.  She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve her family's living condition. 

About CEVI:

Community Economic Ventures, Inc (CEVI) has increased its portfolio significantly over the recent years.  Based in Bohol, they have numerous branches throughout the Philippines.  In 2009, CEVI was awarded a CGAP silver award for transparency in social performance monitoring.  CEVI not only provides credit for its clients but additionally savings, insurance, and training which are provided through regular cluster group meetings.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizers such as manure.

loans.name: Marie Jeanne

texts.en:
Marie Jeanne is 32 years old, married and has four children aged between two and eight. All her children are enrolled in school. 

Marie Jeanne is a tailor, she has done this business for seven years.She is requesting for a loan in order to buy more fabrics. With the profits she plans to renovate her house.

loans.use: To buy more fabrics to sell.

loans.name: Benkan Group

texts.fr:
Les femmes du groupe Benkan, toutes mariées, ont en moyenne 39 ans, 5 enfants et vivent toutes dans des familles traditionnelles élargies dans la ville de Fana,  quartier Banankabougou, préfecture de Dioïla ; Région de Koulikoro (deuxième région  administrative de la république du Mali).
Elles se sont connues à travers des liens de parenté, de voisinage et d’amitié. Elles font la restauration, le commerce de condiments alimentaires, de légumes, des articles en plastiques et de boissons.                                                                                     
Les femmes du groupe Benkan sont à leur dixième prêt solidaire qui sera utilisé pour acheter, du riz, des condiments, des boissons et des légumes.                                                                         
KADIA D. compte acheter, des condiments alimentaires au marché de Fana hebdomadairement. Elle effectue ses ventes quotidiennement sur place à la maison et au marché, au comptant et à crédit, à une clientèle composée essentiellement de femmes.
Elle envisage réaliser un bénéfice moyen mensuel de 25.000F CFA qui sera utilisé pour payer les échéances du prêt, payer les contributions des cérémonies sociales et le reste sera  réinvesti dans son activité de commerce.
texts.en:
The women of the Benkan group, all married, are 39 years old on average with 5 children and live in traditional extended households in the Banankabougou area of the city of Fana in the Dioïla prefecture, Koulikoro region (the second administrative region in the Republic of Mali).
They know each other through familial, neighbourhood, and social relations. They prepare food and sell food condiments, vegetables, plastic items, and beverages.
The women of the Benkan group are on their tenth solidarity (group) loan, which will be used to buy rice, condiments, beverages, and vegetables.
Kadia D., one of the group members, intends to buy food condiments every week at the Fana market. She makes her sales every day at her home and at the market in Marka-Coungo, in cash and on credit, to a clientele composed mainly of women.
She foresees realizing an average monthly profit of 25,000 FCFA, some of which will be used to repay the loan costs and to provide for various familial and social events, with the remainder being reinvested in her business.

loans.use: To buy condiments

loans.name: Honronya Group

texts.fr:
Les quatre femmes du groupe Honronya, toutes mariées, ont en moyenne 35 ans, 5 enfants et vivent toutes dans des familles traditionnelles élargies dans la ville de Fana,  quartier Banankabougou, préfecture de Dioïla, Région de Koulikoro (deuxième région  administrative de la république du Mali).
Elles se sont connues à travers des liens de parenté, de voisinage et d’amitié. Elles font le commerce d’habillements, de légumes et d’articles divers de boutique.                                                                                     
Les femmes du groupe Honronya sont à leur premier prêt solidaire. 
FANTA T. compte acheter,  quelques moquettes à Gao et des pièces de tissus à Bamako presque mensuellement. Elle effectue ses ventes quotidiennement sur place à la maison et au marché, au comptant et à crédit, à une clientèle composée de femmes et d’hommes.
Elle envisage réaliser un bénéfice moyen mensuel de 15.000F CFA qui sera utilisé pour payer les échéances du prêt, payer les contributions des cérémonies sociales et le reste sera  réinvesti dans son activité de commerce.
texts.en:
The four women of the Honronya group, all married, are 35 years old on average with 5 children and live in traditional extended households in the Banankabougou area of the city of Fana in the Dioïla prefecture, Koulikoro region (the second administrative region in the Republic of Mali).
They know each other through familial, neighbourhood, and social relations. They sell clothing, vegetables, and various store items.
The women of the Benkan group are on their first solidarity (group) loan.
Fanta T., one of the group members, intends to buy some moquette in Gao and bolts of fabric in Bamako almost every month. She makes her sales every day at home and at the market in Marka-Coungo, in cash and on credit, to a clientele composed of women and men.
She foresees realizing an average monthly profit of 15,000 FCFA, some of which will be used to repay the loan costs and to provide for various social events, with the remainder being reinvested in her business.

loans.use: To buy pagnes (a type of brightly-printed West African cloth)

loans.name: Martiniana

texts.en:
Martiniana Y. is from the town of San Francisco. She is 50 years old. Martiniana is married and has six children. Four of her children are still going to school. To make a living, Martiniana raises crops, primarily rice, for sale. Martiniana wishes for her children to have bright futures.

Martiniana joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her business and  living situation. Martiniana is requesting a loan of 4,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase seeds, fertilizers and other farm inputs. This will be the first loan taken out by Martiniana from CEVI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve her family's living conditions. 

About CEVI:
Community Economic Ventures, Inc. (CEVI) has increased its portfolio significantly over recent years. Based in Bohol, it has numerous branches throughout the Philippines. In 2009, CEVI was awarded a CGAP silver award for transparency in social performance monitoring. CEVI not only provides its clients credit, but also savings, insurance and training, which are provided through regular cluster group meetings.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase seeds, fertilizers and other farm inputs

loans.name: Chantal

texts.en:
Chantal is 31 years old. She has four children. The youngest is 3 years old, while the eldest is 10 years old. They are all in school and her husband is a primary school teacher. 

Chantal is a tailor. She also sells tailoring materials such as threads, needles and fabric. Chantal is requesting a loan to buy more fabric and make some designs for her clients. She plans to save all her profits in order to make savings for her children’s education.

loans.use: To buy fabric

loans.name: Susan

texts.en:
Susan S. is from the town of San Francisco. She is 42 years old. Susan is married and has three children ages 18, 15 and 8. 

To make a living, Susan raises crops, primarily rice, for sale. Susan works hard in order to support her family financially.

Susan joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her business and living situation. Susan is requesting a loan of 4,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase seeds, fertilizers and other farm inputs. This will be the first loan taken out by Susan from CEVI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to pay for her children's tuition fees. 

About CEVI:
Community Economic Ventures, Inc. (CEVI) has increased its portfolio significantly over recent years. Based in Bohol, it has numerous branches throughout the Philippines. In 2009, CEVI was awarded a CGAP silver award for transparency in social performance monitoring. CEVI not only provides its clients credit, but also savings, insurance and training, which are provided through regular cluster group meetings.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase seeds, fertilizers and other farm inputs

loans.name: Djiguitougou Group

texts.fr:
Les femmes du groupe Djiguitougou, toutes mariées, ont en moyenne 34 ans, 3 enfants et vivent toutes dans des familles traditionnelles élargies dans la ville de Fana,  quartier Guegneka II, préfecture de Dioïla, Région de Koulikoro (deuxième région  administrative de la république du Mali).
Elles se sont connues à travers des liens de parenté, de voisinage, d’amitié et font le commerce d’habillements, des chaussures, des condiments alimentaires, des céréales, de plastiques et de tubercules.                                                                                     
Les femmes du groupe Djiguitougou sont à leur septième prêt solidaire qui sera utilisé pour acheter,  des tissus, des chaussures, des tubercules, des condiments et du riz.                                                                         
AWA T., un des membres du groupe, compte acheter, avec son prêt, 15 sacs de patates douces hebdomadairement au marché de Nangola préfecture de Dioïla. Elle effectue ses ventes quotidiennement sur place à la maison et au marché, en détail, au comptant et à crédit, à une clientèle composée essentiellement de femmes.
Elle espère obtenir un bénéfice moyen mensuel de 40.000 F CFA qui sera utilisé pour payer les échéances du prêt, contribuer aux cérémonies sociales et le reste sera réinvesti dans son activité de commerce de tubercules.
texts.en:
The women of the Djiguitougou group, all married, are 34 years old on average with 3 children and live in traditional extended households in the Guegneka II district of the city of Fana in the Dioïla prefecture, Koulikoro region (the second administrative region in the Republic of Mali).
They know each other through familial, neighbourhood, and social relations. They sell clothing, shoes, food condiments, cereals, plastic items, and yams.
The women of the Djiguitougou group are on their seventh solidarity (group) loan, which will be used to buy fabric, shoes, yams, condiments and rice.
Awa T., one of the group members, intends to use her loan to buy 15 bags of sweet potatoes every week at the market in the Nangola, in the Dioïla prefecture. She makes her sales every day at her home and at the market at retail, in cash and on credit, to a clientele composed mainly of women.
She hopes to realize an average monthly profit of 40,000 FCFA, some of which will be used to repay the loan costs and to provide for various social events, with the remainder being reinvested in her yam-selling business.

loans.use: To buy yams

loans.name: Johan

texts.en:
Johan, 52 years old, is married to Amalia, 53 years old, and has been blessed with a child named Ronald, 18 years old. Johan and his family are living in Tanah Merah village. It is a coastal area and situated about 30 minutes drive from Kupang City. 

Johan is a fishmonger. He has been running this business for years to support his family.
 
Johan usually starts his activities at 5 a.m. He goes to sea for fishing until 8 a.m. Trawling is his only method of fishing, and the net is his only equipment, so he cannot go too far to get the fish. As a result, Johan cannot get many fish and can earn only a small income. Sometimes the fish are only sufficient as side dishes for his family. A challenge faced by Johan is when the monsoon comes. He cannot catch fish at all at that time. 

Johan wants to improve his business by purchasing a small boat to support him in fishing. For this reason, he is requesting a loan amounting to IDR 5,000,000 from TLM. He plans to buy a secondhand boat with the loan. He hopes that the loan will help him to improve his business and family life.

loans.use: To buy a secondhand boat

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy a cow

loans.name: Arlyn

texts.en:
Like most people in the town of San Francisco, Agusan Del Sur, Arlyn B. also ventured into farming. She started her business three years ago. She cultivates her land for planting and harvesting rice crops. Arlyn sells her harvest to rice traders. She says she works hard to sell the best quality rice.

Arlyn currently needs farm inputs such as seeds and fertilizer. She has requested a loan of 4,000 PHP from CEVI, an MFI she recently joined in order to have financial support for her business.

Arlyn is married and has two children, ages 10 and 5. Both of her children are in school. Arlyn does her best to support their education.

loans.use: to purchase seeds and fertilizer

loans.name: Naomi

texts.en:
Naomi was born in 1962. She has eight children; her eldest child is 28 years old while the youngest is 15. Naomi’s husband is currently retired.

She sells charcoal and has done this business since 2001. She is requesting a loan in order to buy more sacks of charcoal. She plans to buy Irish potatoes with the profits she hopes to make.

loans.use: Buying sacks of charcoal.

loans.name: Benkadi Group

texts.fr:
Les quatre femmes du groupe Benkadi sont mariées majoritairement dans des ménages monogames avec en moyenne 38 ans et 5 enfants. Elles habitent toutes dans le quartier Hamdallaye de Ségou (4ème Région administrative du Mali) et se sont connues à travers des liens de parenté, de mariage et de leurs activités de petits commerces dans le marché Château de Ségou. 
Les membres du groupe font l’achat et la vente de couvre lits, pagnes wax, cubes jumbo et  de légumes (choux pommés, tomates fraîches, carottes, piments, aubergines et la laitue). 
Dans le but d’augmenter leur fonds de commerce, les membres du groupe ont adhéré à Soro Yiriwaso et sont à leur 8ème cycle de prêt solidaire.
 Madame Oumou Diabaté est une grande vendeuse de légumes de toutes sortes au marché Château de Ségou. 
Elle compte utiliser son prêt pour acheter, 20 sacs de choux pommés. Elle se ravitaille en légumes avec les forains de Koutiala au grand marché de Ségou. La revente se fait au comptant et à crédit à domicile et au marché Château à une clientèle composée majoritairement de femmes. 
Madame Oumou espère réaliser avec ce prêt un bénéfice mensuel moyen de 35 000FCFA qui sera utilisé pour être réinvesti dans l’activité et prendre en charge certains besoins du foyer. 
Elle a pour ambition d’acheter un lot à usage d’habitation dans ce partenariat avec Soro Yiriwaso / Kiva.
texts.en:
The four women of the Benkadi group are married, live mainly in monogamous households, and are 38 years old on average with 5 children. They all live in the Hamdallaye area of Ségou (4th administrative region of Mali), and know each other through familial, marriage, and business relations - they all run small businesses at the Château market in Ségou.
The group members buy and sell bedspreads, pagnes wax (a type of brightly-printed cloth), Jumbo boullion cubes, and vegetables (cabbage, fresh tomatoes, carrots, peppers, eggplant, and lettuce).
With the goal of increasing their working capital, the group members joined Soro Yiriwaso (one of Kiva's field partners), and are on their 8th solidarity (group) loan cycle. 
Ms. Oumou Diabaté, one of the group members, is a well-known seller of all types of vegetables at the Château market in Ségou.
She intends to use her loan to buy 20 bags of cabbage. She gets her vegetable supplies from the Koutiala stallkeepers at the grand market in Ségou. She re-sells her goods in cash and on credit at home and at the Château market to a clientele composed primarily of women.
With this loan, Ms. Oumou hopes to realize an average monthly profit of 35,000 FCFA, which will be reinvested in her business and used to take care of certain household expenses.
She aspires to buy a plot of land for housing through this partnership with Soro Yiriwaso/Kiva.

loans.use: To buy cabbage

loans.name: Fred

texts.en:
Fred is 53 years old, married and has eight children who are between 7 and 26. His wife works as a farmer.

Fred sells various items such as rice, juice, mineral water and sugar. He has been running his business for 29 years. Fred has requested this loan to buy more rice and sugar. 

He hopes to renovate his house and pay school fees for his children from the profits he anticipates to get from the business. He dreams to get more loans in the future.

loans.use: To buy more items to sell.

loans.name: Lourdes

texts.en:
Lourdes G. is from the town of San Francisco. She is 51 years old. Lourdes is married. To make a living, Lourdes owns and operates a business venture in the agriculture sector raising crops. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from planting and harvesting rice for sale. Lourdes wants to be able to help her family financially, so she does her best to do so.

Lourdes joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Lourdes is requesting a new loan of 4,000 PHP, which will be used to buy seeds and fertilizer. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Lourdes from CEVI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve her business. 

About CEVI:

Community Economic Ventures, Inc (CEVI) has increased its portfolio significantly over the recent years.  Based in Bohol, they have numerous branches throughout the Philippines.  In 2009, CEVI was awarded a CGAP silver award for transparency in social performance monitoring.  CEVI not only provides credit for its clients but additionally savings, insurance and training, which are provided through regular cluster group meetings.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to buy seeds and fertilizer

loans.name: Batmunkh

texts.en:
Batmunkh M. is 53 years old and lives with her husband and daughter in Ulaanbaatar, capital city of Mongolia. Her family lives in a small house in the outer ger districts of the city. She worked as a doctor from 1978 to 1995. Her husband is a micro-entrepreneur while their daughter attends college.

Batmunkh supports her family by operating a jewelry retail stall at Narantuul, the largest outdoor market in Mongolia.

She began her small business in 1995. During past 15 years, she has been successfully expanding her business and was able to improve her living conditions and she has gained a lot of business experience while her family built their own small house in 2005 with 4 million MNT.

Now her working capital is almost 1.5 million MNT, and she mostly sells silver rings for women. She is requesting a 500,000 MNT loan in order to buy more jewelry in this very busy shopping season of the year.

She said "I want to grow my business with this loan, and I would like to be able to operate my own little jewelry store in the future."

loans.use: To purchase silver rings and earrings

loans.name: Violette

texts.en:
Violette is 26 years old. She is the mother of three children; the eldest is 8 years old, while the youngest is 3 years old. 

She owns a store in which she sells various foods, such as rice. She has run this business for eight years and, together with her husband, it has helped her build her own house. She is requesting a loan in order to buy more food stock. She is planning to save all her profits for when she will have enough to build a house.

loans.use: Buying more food stock.

loans.name: Djamadjigui Group

texts.fr:
Les dix femmes du groupe Djamadjigui sont mariées majoritairement dans des ménages monogames avec en moyenne 30 ans et 2 enfants. Elles habitent toutes dans la ville de Ségou au quartier Ségou Coura Bamanan (4ème Région administrative du Mali) et se sont connues à travers des liens de voisinage et de leurs activités génératrices de revenu au marché de Ségou Coura et grand marché de Ségou. 
Les membres du groupe font le petit commerce de  boîtes de concentrée de tomate,  des céréales (riz et haricot), des ustensiles plastiques (tasses, pots et bols),  des habillements (pagnes wax, bazins  et habits  pour enfants) et  des savons à fabrication locale et industrielle. 
Dans le but d’augmenter leur fonds de commerce pour pouvoir s’approvisionner au comptant, les membres du groupe ont intégré Soro Yiriwaso et sont à leur 3ème cycle de prêt solidaire.
Madame Magnama Danté a une grande réputation dans la vente des ustensiles plastiques à Ségou coura. 
Elle compte utiliser son prêt pour acheter, 15 douzaines d’ustensiles plastiques au grand marché  de la ville de Ségou. La revente se fait au comptant et à crédit à domicile, en ambulant et au marché de Ségou coura à une clientèle composée généralement de femmes. 
Madame Magnama Danté espère réaliser avec ce prêt un bénéfice mensuel moyen de 38.000FCFA qui sera utilisé pour être réinvesti dans l’activité et prendre en charge les soins de santé et les frais scolaires des enfants. A l’instar des autres membres du groupe, elle a pour objectif d’acheter un moulin avec son épargne dans ce partenariat avec Soro Yiriwaso.
texts.en:
The ten women of the Djamadjigui group are married, live mainly in monogamous households, and are 30 years old on average with 2 children. They all live in the city of Ségou, in the Ségou Coura Bamanan area (4th administrative region of Mali), and know each other through neighbourhood relations and their businesses at the market in Ségou Coura and the grand market in Ségou.
The group members run small businesses selling cans of tomato concentrate, cereals (rice and beans), plastic cookware (cups, pots, and bowls), clothing (damask, children's clothes, and pagnes wax -  a type of brightly-printed cloth), and soap made locally and industrially.
With the goal of increasing their working capital in order to pay for their supplies in cash, the group members joined Soro Yiriwaso (one of Kiva's field partners) and are on their third solidarity (group) loan cycle.
Ms. Magnama Danté is well-known for the sale of plastic cookware in Ségou Coura.
She intends to use her loan to buy 15 dozen plastic utensiles at the grand market in the city of Ségou. She re-sells her goods in cash and on credit at home, door-to-door, and at the market in Ségou Coura to a clientele composed mainly of women.
With this loan, Ms. Magnama Danté hopes to realize an average monthly profit of 38,000 FCFA, which will be used to reinvest in her business and take care of her children's health and education costs. Following the example of the other group members, her goal is to buy a mill with her savings through this partnership with Soro Yiriwaso.

loans.use: To buy plastic cookware (cups, bowls, and pots)

loans.name: Nenita

texts.en:
Nenita, 36, is a farmer from the town of San Francisco, Agusan Del Sur. She is married and has five children. Her eldest child is 15 years old and the youngest is only 2. Nenita has been farming for five years. She plants and harvests rice crops that she sells to the market. Nenita works hard to earn more, especially now that four of her kids go to school.

Nenita joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Nenita is requesting a new loan of 4,000 PHP, which will be used to buy farm inputs such as seeds and fertilizer. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Nenita from CEVI.

loans.use: to buy farm inputs such as seeds and fertilizer

loans.name: Abarwanashyaka Group

texts.en:
Consolee is 44 years old, married and has five children who range from 14 to 22 years old. She is married to a farmer. 

Consolee is a group leader of a borrowing group called Abarwanashyaka, which means "The Pioneers" in English. The group members sell different items and they have organized themselves to get this loan, which they assume will be helpful in their business. 

Consolee sells beans and drinks. With the help of her colleagues, she requested this loan to buy more beans and drinks to sell. She has been selling these items for a period of eight years. She says the profits she hopes to get will be used to pay school fees and renovate her house. She wishes to raise her loan amount to 300,000 in the future.

loans.use: To buy more beans and drinks to sell.

loans.name: Ichinkhorloo

texts.en:
Ichinkhorloo A. is 44, is a mother of three and micro-entrepreneur. She lives with her husband, three daughters and younger sister, who has a disability, in Ulaanbaatar, capital city of Mongolia. Her family lives in a small house in the outer ger districts of the city. Her hobby is floriculture. There are many flowers in her home, which makes her home cozy and inviting.  Ichinkhorloo is a very caring person who takes care of her sister. Her husband is a car dealer while her older two daughters attend college and youngest daughter is in secondary school.  Thus, her children’s education expense is quite high.  

Ichinkhorloo supports her family by operating a jewelry retail stall at Narantuul, the largest outdoor market in Mongolia. She began her business in 2000. She sells silver rings, necklaces, earrings and bracelets to local customers. Now her working capital is 1.7 million MNT. She purchases her products from a wholesale supplier who brings jewelry directly from Turkey. 

With this loan of 500,000 MNT, Ichinkhorloo will purchase more jewelry before the Mongolian Lunar New Year Holiday, and she believes this loan will help support her in this very busy shopping season of the year.

She wants to expand her business with Kiva loans and be able to support her children’s education and their future goals.

loans.use: To purchase silver rings and earrings

loans.name: Benkadi Group

texts.fr:
Les quatre femmes du groupe Benkadi sont mariées majoritairement dans des ménages polygames avec une moyenne d’âge de 47 ans et 5 enfants. Elles vivent à Pelengana Nord, chef lieu d’une commune rurale dans la région de Ségou (4ème Région administrative du Mali) et se sont connues à travers des liens de voisinage et de leurs activités génératrices de revenu dans le quartier. 
Les membres du groupe font le petit commerce de savon local, du charbon de bois, des pagnes wax, fancy et bazins. 
Dans le besoin d’augmenter leur fonds de commerce, les membres du groupe ont adhéré à Soro Yiriwaso et sont à leur 4ème cycle de prêt solidaire.
Madame Kadiata Kaklé est une fabricante et vendeuse de savon locale connu sous le nom de «Touloudiè Safinè » à Pelengana Nord. C’est un savon réputé, apprécié et recherché au Mali pour ses propriétés médicinales.  
Kadiata compte utiliser son prêt pour acheter, des colis de beurre de karité et une grande quantité de potasse auprès des grossistes de la place. 
Pour le fabriquer, on imbibe avec de l’eau, les cendres obtenus par brûlure des fanes de récolte, le filtrat recueilli est ensuite mis au feu dans une poêle pendant 2 heures de temps au moins. Après refroidissement, il est malaxé avec le beurre de karité et la potasse jusqu’à l’obtention d’une pâte qu’est le savon. Il est ensuite découpé par morceaux destinés à la vente. 
Elle vend au comptant et à crédit, à domicile, en ambulant et au marché de Pelengana Nord à une clientèle composée généralement de femmes. 
Madame Kadiata Kaklé espère réaliser avec ce prêt un bénéfice mensuel moyen de 31.250 FCFA qui sera utilisé pour être réinvesti dans l’activité et assurer les frais scolaires des enfants.
texts.en:
The four women of the Benkadi group are married, live primarily in monogamous households, and are 47 years old on average with 5 children. They live in North Pelengana, the administrative centre of a rural district in the Ségou region (4th administrative region of Mali), and know each other through neighbourhood relations and their income-generating businesses in the area.
The group members run small businesses selling locally-made soap, charcoal, and pagnes (a type of brightly-printed cloth) of the wax, fancy, and bazin (damask) styles.
With the goal of increasing their working capital, the group members joined Soro Yiriwaso (one of Kiva's field partners) and are on their fourth solidarity (group) loan cycle.
Ms. Kadiata Kaklé, one of the group members, manufactures and sells locally-made soap known by the name "Touloudiè Safinè" in North Pelangana. It is a highly reputed, appreciated, and sought-after soap in Mali because of its medicinal properties.
Kadiata intends to use her loan to buy packets of shea butter and a large amount of potash from the wholesalers in the area. 
To make the soap, the ashes obtained by burning the harvest waste are soaked in water, and the collected filtrate is then heated in a stove for about two hours. After cooling, it is mixed with shea butter and potash until it becomes a soap-like paste. It is then cut into pieces and sold.
She sells her goods in cash and on credit at home, door-to-door, and at the market in North Pelengana to a clientele composed mainly of women.
With this loan, Ms. Kadiata Kaklé hopes to realize an average monthly profit of 31,250 FCFA, which will be used to reinvest in her business and pay for her children's school fees.

loans.use: To buy raw materials to make local soap (potash and shea butter)

loans.name: Monica

texts.en:
Monica W. W., 38, sells clothes to earn a living. She runs her business in an open-air market. She also does farming to supplement her income.  

She was able to start her business with help from Faulu Kenya. She dreams of expanding her business and  providing quality education to her children.  

She needs 20,000 KES to buy more clothes to sell.

loans.use: To buy clothes to sell

loans.name: Shabani

texts.en:
Shabani is 40 years old. He has four children. His eldest is 15 years old while the youngest is 4 years old. Three are in school and the youngest is planning to begin school this year. 

Shabani owns a shop in which he sells sugar, cooking oil and some food staffs. He has done this business for seven years.

With the help of his business,he was able to build a house. Shabani is requesting a loan to buy more food staffs so that he can make more profits and support his family.With the profits,Shabani wishes to expand her business.

loans.use: To buy more food staffs to sell.

loans.name: Gina

texts.en:
Gina F., 31 years old, is from the town of Trento. She is married and has four school-aged children. 

To make a living, Gina plants and harvests rice for sale. Aside from rice farming, she also grows hogs and runs a sari-sari store. Gina does her best to manage her businesses and her family well.

Gina joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her business and living situation. She has successfully repaid a previous loan  from CEVI. 

Gina is requesting a new loan of 8,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase farm inputs and pig feed. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to save as a reserve for future emergencies.

loans.use: To purchase farm inputs and pig feed

loans.name: Sabougnouman Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe Sabougnouman est constitué de 4 femmes toutes mariées dans des ménages monogames avec en moyenne 33 ans et 4 enfants. Elles vivent à Pelengana Nord, chef lieu d’une commune rurale dans la région de Ségou (4eme Région administrative du Mali). 
Elles se sont connues à travers des liens de voisinage et de leurs activités de commerce d’habits dans le quartier. Les membres du groupe font le petit commerce de pagnes wax, fancy et rideaux pour les portes et fenêtres.  
Dans le souci d’augmenter leur fonds de commerce, les membres du groupe ont intégré Soro Yiriwaso et sont à leur 4eme cycle de prêt solidaire.
Madame Adjaratou M. est connue à Pelengana Nord pour sa vente de pagnes nouvellement imprimés à la COMATEX (Compagnie Malienne des Textiles) basée à Ségou ville. 
Elle compte utiliser son prêt pour acheter, 20 pièces de pagnes à la COMATEX. La revente se fait au comptant et à crédit, à domicile, en ambulant et au marché de Pelengana Nord à une clientèle composée de femmes et d’hommes. Madame Adjaratou M. vend parfois sur commande (uniformes) aux associations féminines et lors des cérémonies de mariage. 
Elle espère réaliser avec ce prêt un bénéfice mensuel moyen de 35.000 FCFA qui sera utilisé pour être réinvesti dans l’activité et prendre en charge les besoins du foyer. Elle a pour objectif d’acheter une maison à usage d’habitation dans ce partenariat avec Soro Yiriwaso.
texts.en:
The Sabougnouman group comprises 4 women, all married, who live in monogamous households and are 33 years old on average with 4 children. They live in North Pelengana, the administrative centre of a rural commune in the Ségou region (4th administrative region of Mali).
They know each other through neighbourhood relations and their clothing businesses in the area. The group members run small businesses selling pagnes (a type of brightly-printed cloth) of the 'wax' and 'fancy' styles, as well as curtains for doors and windows.
With the goal of increasing their working capital, the group members joined Soro Yiriwaso (one of Kiva's field partners) and are on their fourth solidarity (group) loan cycle. 
Ms. Adjaratou M., one of the group members, is known in North Pelengana for selling pagnes newly printed by COMATEX (The Malian Textile Company) based in the city of Ségou.
She intends to use her loan to buy 20 sets of pagnes from COMATEX. She re-sells her goods in cash and on credit at home, door-to-door, and at the market in North Pelengana to a clientele composed of women and men. Ms. Adjaratou M. also sometimes sells made-to-order goods (special uniforms) to women's associations and for marriage ceremonies.
With this loan, she hopes to realize an average monthly profit of 35,000 FCFA, which will be used to reinvest in her business and take care of the household expenses. Her goal is to buy a house through this partnership with Soro Yiriwaso.

loans.use: To buy pagnes (a type of brightly-printed cloth)

loans.name: Judith

texts.en:
Judith T. is a rice farmer from the town of Trento, Agusan Del Sur. She is 33 years old, married and has two young children. 

Judith has been planting and harvesting rice crops for five years now. She usually sells her harvest to rice traders. Aside from rice farming, she also grows pigs in her backyard. She fattens the pigs and sells them to the market.

Judith joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her business and living situation. Judith has successfully repaid a previous loan  from CEVI. Judith is requesting a new loan of 7,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase pig feed and farm inputs. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to support her family.

loans.use: To purchase pig feed and farm inputs

loans.name: Paulette

texts.en:
Paulette is a mother of four children; the eldest is 7 years while the youngest is 11 months. Paulette has a store in which she sells soap, Vaseline, sugar and rice. 

Paulette is requesting a loan in order to buy more sugar, soap, Vaseline and rice in order to fill her store and hence make more profits. She is planning to buy more items with the profits she hopes to make.

loans.use: To buy sugar, soap and Vaseline

loans.name: Nilda

texts.en:
Nilda S. is from the town of Trento. She is 26 years old. Nilda is married and has 2 young children. To make a living, Nilda owns & operates a business venture in the agriculture sector raising livestock. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from raising pigs for fattening and sale. Nilda also helps her husband maintain their rice farm. 

Nilda joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Nilda has successfully repaid a previous loan  from CEVI. Nilda is requesting a new loan of 8000 PHP which will be used to buy seeds, fertilizers and pig feeds. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve her family's living conditions.

loans.use: to buy seeds, fertilizer and pig feed

loans.name: Chaka

texts.fr:
Monsieur Chaka T. est âgé de 33 ans, marié et père d’un enfant. Il vit dans une famille traditionnelle avec sa mère et leurs frères au quartier Pelengana village de la commune de Pelengana (quatrième région administrative de la république du Mali).
N’ayant pas fréquenté pour des raisons sociales, (analphabétisme des parents surtout très versé dans l’islam). Il commença le petit commerce auprès d’un ami qui tenait une boutique de quincaillerie au quartier Pelengana près de la gare routière. 
Après 6 années d’expériences auprès de ce dernier, il évolua seul maintenant en menant le commerce de céréales (mil, riz, etc.) et de potasses, depuis 4 ans. Il jouit d’une grande clientèle, sa force de vente est due à la qualité de son article.    
Dans le but de satisfaire sa demande clientèle, il rentre en relation avec Soro Yiriwaso. Il est à son 1er prêt, qu’il compte utiliser pour acheter 2.200 kg de riz. Il s’approvisionne dans la zone office du Niger auprès des producteurs. 
Monsieur Chaka T. vend au comptant et à crédit à une clientèle composée d’hommes et de femmes.
Il compte réaliser un bénéfice mensuel de 60 000 FCFA, qui lui sert à rembourser son prêt et  contribuer aux dépenses de la famille. 
Son ambition est de développer son commerce.
texts.en:
Mr. Chaka T. is 33 years old, married and father to one child. He lives in a traditional family with his mother and brothers in the Pelengana village district of the municipality of Pelengana(the Republic of Mali's fourth administrative region).

He did not attend school for social reasons (illiteracy of his parents who were very committed to their islam religion) and began trading on a small scale with a friend who had a hardware store in the Pelengana district close to the bus station. After six years working with his friend he began four years ago to develop his own business, trading in cereals (millet, rice, etc.) and potashes. He enjoys a large customer base and his sales strength is the quality of his products. 

With the aim of satisfying customer demand he has entered into a relationship with Soro Yiriwaso. He is on his first loan which he is planning to use to buy 2,200 kg of rice. He gets his supplies from wholesalers in the area surrounding the office area of Niger.

Mr. Chaka T. sells for cash and credit to a customer base made up of men and women. He is expecting to make a monthly profit of 60,000FCFA which will be used to repay his loan and contribute to family expenses. His ambition is to build up his business.

loans.use: To buy cereals

loans.name: Vergie

texts.en:
Vergie lives in the town of Trento, Agusan Del Sur with her family. She is married and has 2 children aged 14 and 6. Vergie and her husband are both farmers. They have been tilling their rice farm for over a decade now. A few years back, Vergie decided to raise pigs to have another source of income. Vergie works hard to improve her small piggery.

Vergie joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Vergie has successfully repaid a previous loan  from CEVI. Vergie is requesting a new loan of 8000 PHP which will be used to purchase farm supplies and pig feed. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to pay for her children's tuition fees. 

About CEVI:

Community Economic Ventures, Inc (CEVI) has increased its portfolio significantly over the recent years.  Based in Bohol, they have numerous branches throughout the Philippines.  In 2009, CEVI was awarded a CGAP silver award for transparency in social performance monitoring.  CEVI not only provides credit for its clients but additionally savings, insurance, and training which are provided through regular cluster group meetings.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase farm supplies and pig feed

loans.name: Rokia

texts.fr:
Madame Rokia K. est âgée de 31 ans, mariée et mère de 4 enfants, elle vit dans une famille traditionnelle avec sa mère et leurs frères au quartier Médine de la ville de Ségou (quatrième région administrative de la république du Mali).
N’ayant pas fréquenté pour des raisons sociales, elle fréquenta l’école coranique. Elle commença le petit commerce auprès de sa mère qui vendait des habits et chaussures au marché Médine. Après plusieurs années auprès de cette dernière, elle évolue seule actuellement et mène le commerce d’habits et chaussures depuis 15 ans. Elle jouit d’une grande clientèle, sa force de vente est due à la qualité de ses habits.    
Dans le but de satisfaire sa demande clientèle, qu’elle sollicite un nouveau prêt, elle est en relation avec Soro Yiriwaso depuis 66 mois. Après 5 prêts solidaires et 3 prêts individuels correctement bien remboursés.  
Elle est à son 4ème prêt, qu’elle compte utiliser pour acheter 1 pièce de Bazin riche et 5 pièces de bazins moins riches. Elle s’approvisionne sur place. 
Madame Rokia K. vend au comptant et à crédit à une clientèle composée d’hommes et de femmes. 
Avec ce prêt, elle compte réaliser un bénéfice mensuel de 100 000 FCFA, qui lui sert à rembourser son prêt et pour la prise en charge des dépenses familiales.
texts.en:
Mrs. Rokia K. is 31 years old, married, and the mother of four children. She lives in a traditional family that includes her mother and her brothers in the district of Médine, in the city of Ségou (fourth administrative region of the Republic of Mali).

Due to social reasons, she only attended Koranic school. She became involved in small trade with her mother who was selling clothes and shoes at the Médine market. After several years working alongside her mother, she branched out on her own and has now been selling clothing and footwear for 15 years. She has a large customer base, and her main asset lies in the high quality of the clothes that she sells. 

In order to meet customer demand, she is seeking a new loan from the Soro Yiriwaso MFI. During her 66-month collaboration with the organization, she benefited from five group loans and three individual loans, all fully repaid. 

She is now on her fourth individual loan, which she will use to buy one bolt of rich damask fabric and five bolts of regular damask fabric. She buys her stocks locally. 

Mrs. Rokia K. sells for cash and credit to a customer base of both men and women. With this loan, she expects to make a monthly profit of 100,000 FCFA, which she will use to repay the loan and take care of family expenses.

loans.use: To buy clothing

loans.name: Florenda

texts.en:
Florenda H. is from the town of Sta. Josefa. She is 59 years old. Florenda is married. To make a living, Florenda owns & operates a business venture in the agriculture sector raising crops. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from planting and harvesting rice for sale. 

Florenda joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Florenda has successfully repaid a previous loan  from CEVI. Florenda is requesting a new loan of 7000 PHP which will be used to purchase farm supplies like seeds and fertilizer. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement the family's income.

loans.use: to purchase farm supplies like seeds and fertilizers

loans.name: Marlyn

texts.en:
Marlyn V. is from the town of Sta. Josefa. She is 34 years old. Marlyn is married. To make a living, Marlyn owns & operates a business venture in the agriculture sector raising crops. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from planting and harvesting rice for sale. Marlyn works hard for family. She hopes for her farm to be productive always.

Marlyn joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Marlyn has successfully repaid a previous loan  from CEVI. Marlyn is requesting a new loan of 5000 PHP which will be used to buy rice seeds, fertilizer and other farm supplies. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve her family's living conditions.

loans.use: to buy rice seeds, fertilizer and other farm supplies

loans.name: Nicasio

texts.en:
Nicasio C. is from the town of Sta. Josefa. She is 48 years old. Nicasio is married and has 3 children aged 21, 18 and 14. To make a living, Nicasio owns & operates a business venture in the agriculture sector raising crops. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from planting and harvesting rice and corn for sale. Nicasio currently earns approximately 3000 PHP every month from farming. He hopes for his harvest to increase.

Nicasio joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Nicasio has successfully repaid a previous loan  from CEVI. Nicasio is requesting a new loan of 7000 PHP which will be used to buy seeds and fertilizer.

loans.use: to buy seeds and fertilizer

loans.name: Jiguisseme Group

texts.fr:
Les membres du groupe JIGUISSEME sont toutes mariés avec une moyenne d’âge de 42 ans et en moyenne 4 enfants. Elles vivent dans des familles monogames à MEDINE un des quartiers de la ville de Sikasso 3ème région administrative du Mali. 
Elles sont à leur neuvième collaboration avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso afin de satisfaire le besoin de leur clientèle, les prêts passé ont été remboursé dans de bonne condition. Ce groupe de femmes fait le commerce de tissus et  des oranges à travers MAIMOUNA D.. 
MAIMOUNA D.  compte acheter avec son  prêt, 30 sacs d’oranges .
Elle s’approvisionne auprès des producteurs de SIKASSO. Les oranges sont revendus au  marché de MEDINE à Sikasso et en famille à une clientèle composée d’hommes et de femmes au comptant et en détail. 
 Elle envisage réaliser un bénéfice mensuel moyen de 95.000 FCFA utilisée pour les dépenses quotidiennes de la famille.
texts.en:
The members of the group named Jiguisseme are all married and they are 42 years old on average. They each have 4 children. They live in monogamous families in Medine, a quarter in the city of Sikasso (third administrative region in Mali). 

They are on their ninth group loan with the microfinance institution Soro Yiriwaso (Kiva Field Partner) and their goal is to satisfy their clients' needs. The previous loans were successfully repaid. This group of women sells fabrics and oranges through Maimouna D.. 

Maimouna D. plans on investing her loan in the purchase of 30 sacks of oranges. 

She purchases her products from the producers in Sikasso. The oranges are resold in the market in Medine, Sikasso, and to family. Her clientele is made up of men and women and she takes cash and credit. 

She plans on earning a monthly income of 95.000 FCFA and it will be used to supply her family's daily needs.

loans.use: To purchase oranges.

loans.name: Kodamine Group

texts.fr:
Les membres du groupe KODAMINE (4 mariés et 1 veuve) ont en moyenne 30 ans, 2 enfants et vivent la plupart dans des familles monogames à SANOUBOUGOU I un des quartiers de la ville de Sikasso 3ème région administrative du Mali. 
Elles sont à leur deuxième collaboration avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso afin de satisfaire le besoin de leur clientèle, le prêt passé a été remboursé dans de bonne condition. Ce groupe de femmes fait le commerce de tissus brodés à travers ASSITAN C.. 
ASSITAN C. compte acheter avec son prêt, 35 pagnes de  tissus brodés. Elle s’approvisionne au grand marché de Sikasso. Elle effectue sa vente au marché de SANOUBOUGOU I à Sikasso et en famille à une clientèle composée d’hommes et de femmes, en détail et au comptant.  
Elle envisage réaliser un bénéfice mensuel moyen de 45.000FCFA utilisée pour les dépenses quotidiennes de la famille et rembourser le prêt.
texts.en:
The members of the KODAMINE group are 4 married women and one widow. They average 30 years of age and 2 children, and most of them live in monogamous families in SANOUBOUGOU I, one of the neighborhoods in Sikasso, in the third administrative region of Mali.

They are seeking their second loan from Kiva's partner, the microfinance organization Soro Yiriwaso, in order to meet customer demand. The previous loan was repaid without problems. This group of women trades embroidered fabrics through ASSITAN C..

ASSITAN C. intends to use her loan to buy 35 embroidered "pagnes" (colorful African cloth). She gets her supplies at the grand market in Sikasso. She resells, for cash and on credit, at the SANOUBOUGOU I market in Sikasso, as well as at her home, to a clientele comprising men and women.

She foresees turning a monthly profit of XOF 45'000 (ca US$ 90), to be used to provide for her family's daily expenses and to repay the loan.

loans.use: To buy and resell cloth

loans.name: Elona

texts.en:
Elona B. is from the town of Sta. Josefa. She is 42 years old. Elona is married and has 4 children aged 23, 21, 16 and 9. To make a living, Elona owns & operates a business venture in the agriculture sector raising livestock. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from raising pigs for fattening and sale. Elona also helps her husband keep their rice farm productive.

Elona joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Elona has successfully repaid a previous loan  from CEVI. Elona is requesting a new loan of 16,000 PHP which will be used to purchase farm inputs and pig feed. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to support her family financially.

loans.use: to purchase farm inputs and pig feed

loans.name: Sabati Group

texts.fr:
Les six membres du groupe SABATI sont toutes mariés avec une moyenne d’âge de 30 ans, et en moyenne 4 enfants. Elles vivent dans des familles monogamiques à SANOUBOUGOU I un des quartiers de la ville de Sikasso 3ème région administrative du Mali. 
Elles sont à leur deuxième collaboration avec l’institution de micro finance Soro Yiriwaso afin de satisfaire le besoin de leur clientèle, le prêt passé a été remboursé dans de bonne condition. Ce groupe de femmes fait le commerce d’articles divers tels les condiments alimentaires avec  FATOUMATA C.. 
FATOUMATA C.  compte acheter avec son  prêt, 10 paniers de tomates et 10 kg d’oignons au grand marché de Sikasso. Les condiments sont revendus au  marché de SANOUBOUGOU I et en famille à une clientèle composée d’hommes et de femmes, en détail et au comptant. 
 Elle envisage réaliser un bénéfice mensuel moyen de 40.000 FCFA utilisée pour les dépenses quotidiennes de la famille.
texts.en:
The six members of the SABATE group are all married, with an average age of 30, and an average of 4 children. They live in monogamous families in Sanoubougou I, a district of the city of Sikasso, third administrative region of Mali. 
This is the second loan they are requesting from the micro finance institution Soro Yiriwaso in order to meet the needs of their customers. Their past loan was regularly repaid. This group of women sells sundry items such as condiments and the person in charge of this is Fatoumata C.. 
With this loan she intends to buy 10 baskets of tomatoes and 10 kg of onions at the big market of Sikasso. Their condiments are sold at the market of Sanoubougou I and among family members, to men and women, retail and cash. 
Their expectation is to earn an average monthly profit of 40,000 FCFA to use for the daily expenses of their families.

loans.use: Purchase of condiments ingredients

loans.name: Robinah

texts.en:
Robinah is a mother of four children; the youngest is sixteen years old while the eldest is eighteen years old and they all attend school. Robinah is a widow and she is very hard-working. Robinah sells paint; her shop is called 'gift shop' and she has been in this business for two years. 

Robinah is requesting a loan in order to buy more paint. She has been selling house paint but she would like to sell car paint as well. With the profits she hopes to increase her capital to be able to expand her business in the future.

loans.use: To buy more paint to sell

loans.name: Melissa

texts.en:
Melissa L. is from the town of Sta. Josefa. She is 36 years old. Melissa is married and has five children. Her eldest child is 15 years old and the youngest is only 4. To make a living, Melissa owns & operates a business venture in the agriculture sector raising livestock. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from raising pigs for fattening and sale. Melissa also tills a rice farm. She sells her harvest at the market.

Melissa joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Melissa has successfully repaid a previous loan  from CEVI. Melissa is requesting a new loan of 6000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional piglets, feed and vitamins. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to pay her children's tuition fees.

loans.use: to purchase additional piglets, feed and vitamins

loans.name: Sop Mame Cheikh Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe de solidarité SOP MAME CHEIKH est créé le 14 décembre 2008. Il est composé de 11 femmes issues du même quartier. Ces femmes se sont organisées par voisinage et par affinité. Le groupe fait partie du Banc Villageois de KEUR SERIGNE LOUGA EST.

Madame SODA F., debout à l'extrême droit sur la photo vêtue de grand boubou mauve est responsable du groupe. Elle est âgée de 56 ans. Elle est mariée et mère de 05 enfants. 

Son mari est détenteur d'un magasin de vente de pièces détachées de voiture, de matériels électrogènes, de mini-chaines de secondes mains et de moteurs de réfrigérateurs. Les prêts qu'elle consent auprès de CAURIE-MF lui permettent de participer à l'achat de la marchandise. 

Les bénéfices dégagés à partir de ce commerce servent à contribuer au bien-être familial, au payement de la scolarité des enfants et à assurer la couverture sanitaire de la famille. 

Son objectif est d'aider son mari à renforcer le magasin en marchandises
texts.en:
The group called Sop Mame Cheikh was created on the 14th of December, 2008. It is comprised of 11 women who all come from the same neighborhood. These women know each other through family and as friends. The group works with the Banc Villageois of Keur Serigne Louga Est.

Mrs. Sado F., who is on the far right of the photo above and is wearing the mauve gown, is the head of the group. She is 56 years old. She is married and the mother of five children.

Her husband is the owner of a shop selling car parts, materials, generators, a small selection of second-hand engines and refrigerator motors. Loans from MF-Caurie (a microfinance institution) enable him to purchase goods for resale. 

The profits from the business contribute to the family's welfare, to paying for their children's school fees and providing health care for the family.

Her goal is to help her husband improve the store's merchandise.

loans.use: To develop and grow their business

loans.name: Benkadi Group

texts.fr:
Les quatre femmes du groupe BENKADI sont toutes mariées avec une moyenne d’âge de 26 ans, ont en moyenne 2 enfants. Elles vivent la plupart dans des familles monogames au quartier MEDINE un des quartiers de la ville de Sikasso 3ème région administrative du Mali. 
Elles sont à leur onzième collaboration avec l’institution de micro finance Soro Yiriwaso afin de satisfaire le besoin de leur clientèle, les prêts passé ont été remboursé dans de bonne condition. Ce groupe de femmes fait le commerce des habits pour enfants à travers OUMOU D., qui  compte acheter avec son  prêt, 2 balles  de friperie d’habits pour enfants, au grand marché de  Bamako. Les habits sont revendus au  marché de MEDINE à Sikasso et en famille à une clientèle composée d’hommes et de femmes, en détail, au comptant et souvent à crédit. 
Elle envisage réaliser un bénéfice mensuel moyen de 95.000FCFA utilisée pour les dépenses quotidiennes de la famille.
texts.en:
The four women that make up the Benkadi loan group are all married and are an average age of 26 years old, with two children.  They live in the Medine quarter of the city of Siskasso, the third administrative region of Mali. They are mainly from monogamous families.

The group is taking their 11th group loan with the Soro Yiriwaso microfinance bank to meet their customers needs. Their previous loans have been successfully repaid. These women are in the business of selling childrens clothing through hawking. 

Olimou D. plans to use her loan to buy two bales of children's clothing from the main market at Bamako. The cloths will be resold at the Medine market in Sikasso to her family and to clients made up for both man and women, at retail, for cash and credit. She expects to earn an average monthly profit of 95,000 Francs CFA that will be used to meet her family needs.

loans.use: To buy childrens clothing

loans.name: Nelson

texts.en:
Nelson D. is from the town of Sta. Josefa. He is 57 years old. Nelson is married. To make a living, Nelson owns & operates a business venture in the agriculture sector raising crops. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from planting and harvesting rice for sale. 

Nelson joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Nelson has successfully repaid a previous loan  from CEVI. Nelson is requesting a new loan of 12,000 PHP which will be used to purchase fertilizers and seeds. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to support his family financially.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizers and seeds

loans.name: Alphonsine

texts.en:
Alphonsine is a mother of two children who are aged five and ten years; they are both in school. Her husband is a motorcyclist. Alphonsine has a shop in which she sells various items such as salt, matchboxes, soap, etc. She has been in this business for four years and her business is getting on well. 

Alphonsine is requesting a loan in order to buy more items such as sugar, maize flour, etc., that are commonly wanted in her neighborhood. Alphonsine plans to put aside savings from the profits until she can afford to buy a motorcycle.

loans.use: Buying household necessities to sell in her shop

loans.name: Danaya Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe DANAYA  est constitue de 7 mariés et 1veuve  ayant une moyenne d’âge de 36  ans,  en moyenne  5 enfants, vivent la plupart dans des  familles monogames au quartier SANOUBOUGOU I un des quartiers de la ville de Sikasso 3ème région administrative du Mali. 
Elles sont à leur sixième collaboration avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso afin de satisfaire le besoin de leur clientèle, les prêts passé ont été remboursé dans de bonne condition. Ce groupe de femmes fait le commerce de bois de chauffe et de charbons de bois à travers  FATOUMATA K., qui  compte acheter avec son  prêt, 1 chargement de camion 10 tonnes en bois de chauffe. Elle s’approvisionne dans les villages avoisinants Sikasso. Les bois sont revendus en famille à une clientèle composée d’hommes et de femmes, en détail, à crédit et au comptant. 
Elle envisage réaliser un bénéfice mensuel moyen de 90.000FCFA utilisée pour les dépenses quotidiennes de la famille et rembourser le prêt.
texts.en:
Danaya Group ("Confidence") is composed of seven married women and one widow, who on average are 36 years old and have five children. Most of them live in monogamous families in Sanoubougou I, a neighborhood of the city of Sikasso (third administrative region of Mali).

This is their sixth group loan from the microfinance institution Soro Yiriwaso to satisfy the needs of their customers. Their previous loans have been repaid on schedule.

The women in this group trade with firewood and charcoal. Mrs Fatoumata K. intends to use her loan to buy a truckload of firewood (10 tons). She gets her supplies in nearby villages of the Sikasso region. She will retail the firewood, for cash and credit, to a clientele made up of men and women.

Mrs K. expects to make an average profit of 90,000 CFA francs a month, which she will use to provide for her family and repay her loan.

loans.use: To buy firewood

loans.name: Jane

texts.en:
Jane T. is from the town of Trento. She is 45 years old. Jane is married and has 4 children aged 21, 20, 16 and 6. To make a living, Jane owns & operates a business venture in the agriculture sector raising crops. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from planting and harvesting rice for sale.

Jane joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Jane has successfully repaid a previous loan  from CEVI. Jane is requesting a new loan of 7000 PHP which will be used to purchase seeds, chemicals and fertilizers. Jane wishes to have her own money for capital so that she would not need to borrow anymore.

loans.use: to purchase seeds, chemicals and fertilizer

loans.name: Yvonne(Done)

texts.en:
Yvonne is 33 years. She has two children who are 8 and 6 years old. Her husband is a welder and they have always worked together in order to bring up their children in an appropriate way. Yvonne has a store with a variety of goods such as beans, sugar, vaseline and soap. Yvonne has done this business since 2004 and it has enabled her build a small house. 

She is requesting for a loan in order to buy more items for her store. With the profits she hopes to buy more food supplies to put in her store.

loans.use: Buying items for her shop.

loans.name: Mary Ann

texts.en:
Mary Ann M. is from the town of Trento. She is 39 years old and married. She has 5 children aged 21, 19, 18, 12 and 10. To make a living, Mary Ann owns & operates a business venture in the agriculture sector raising livestock.
